data.reading_mnemonic: As you spin a bit in <kanji>midair</kanji> you look up and see <reading>Chew</reading>bacca (<ja>ちゅう</ja>) looking down at you from a spaceship. He's laughing his Chewbacca laugh and you realize he has you trapped in his tractor beam.
data.reading_hint: Oh Chewbacca, you lovable fuzzball. You better not drop me in midair, or I'll die. I hope you bring me up there!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You'll work your <radical>soul</radical> to <radical>death</radical> if you're too <kanji>busy</kanji>. Being busy just isn't good for your soul. Take breaks. Go on vacation. Don't be so busy that you destroy yourself.
data.meaning_hint: Look around you. See all those busy people? Their souls are dying. Don't end up like them.
data.reading_mnemonic: Take time out of your <kanji>busy</kanji> life and go <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) once in a while. In fact, you should probably go bowling once a week at least. Nothing brings energy back to your life like some relaxing bowling.
data.reading_hint: Think about your busy schedule this week. Now cancel everything and just go bowling instead.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>flag</radical> <radical>loiter</radical>s in a <radical>black hole</radical>. This flag marks (in the black hole) where you left your <kanji>boots</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: If you look into the black hole, you can see your boots right there, marked with the flag.
data.reading_mnemonic: You grab your <kanji>boots</kanji> from the black hole. In your boots (thanks to the shelter they provided), some <reading>ree</reading>ds (<ja>り</ja>) have grown in!
data.reading_hint: It's amazing that these cute little reeds could grow in your boots in the middle of a black hole. As a great philosopher once said: "life will find a way."

data.meaning_mnemonic: Use your <radical>mouth</radical> to take a <radical>measurement</radical> of this <kanji>group</kanji>. Just stretch your mouth out and around every single person. Get 'em all in there.
data.meaning_hint: I hope this group is full of people who enjoy being inside someone else's mouth, because they're gonna be pretty mad when you let them out if they aren't.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>group</kanji> is so big it takes you till <reading>dawn</reading> (<ja>だん</ja>) to get your measurement: they weigh a <reading>ton</reading> (<ja>とん</ja>) too!
data.reading_hint: Imagine letting this group of, now very wet, people out of your mouth one by one. They don't seem to care that they weigh a ton! That's a large measurement, they should be proud.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>sun</radical> gets <radical>together</radical> with <radical>water</radical>, only <kanji>violence</kanji> can ensue. They don’t mix well together. The sun loves to fight water and water loves to fight the sun. Lots and lots of violence.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this violent fight scene in your brain. Imagine water locked in battle with the sun as the sun’s fire flares up and the water starts to sizzle.
data.reading_mnemonic: But after a while, the sun and the water have had enough of <kanji>violence</kanji>. They decide to settle their differences with a friendly game of <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>). Bowling is a great way to relieve stress and in the end, they bond over it.
data.reading_hint: Imagine the sun and the water trying to bowl. Hear the sound of bowling balls rolling down the lane and pins rattling around and crashing together.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Compare</radical> the <radical>sun</radical> with a <radical>tsunami</radical> – these two things don’t <kanji>mix</kanji>. If a tsunami is coming, it will likely get in the way of the sun.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the sun getting blocked out as a tsunami rises up from the ocean. Feel the cold fear of death on you as the tsunami approaches. That tsunami is gonna mix you up.
data.reading_mnemonic: Just before the tsunami crashes over you, a <reading>con</reading>dor (<ja>こん</ja>) swoops out of the sky and grabs you up. This condor must be a <kanji>mix</kanji> – a normal condor is not strong enough to pick up a human. The condor must be mixed with something else. Like a pterodactyl.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself getting mixed up in this situation and the pterodactyl sized condor picking you up. Feel the condor’s talons digging into your shoulders as it grabs you up and flies you towards the sun.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you stab somebody in the <radical>tongue</radical> with an <radical>umbrella</radical>, it’s sure to start a <kanji>riot</kanji>. Nobody likes to get stabbed in the tongue with an umbrella, so they’re probably going to retaliate, and before you know it, you’ve a full scale riot on your hands. Look what you’ve done.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself getting stabbed in the tongue with an umbrella. It’s very painful. Taste the blood and metal in your mouth as this happens to you.
data.reading_mnemonic: Just now you realize that the man you stabbed in the tongue with your umbrella was none other than Macho Man <reading>Ran</reading>dy Savage (<ja>らん</ja>). Being a professional wrestler, Macho Man Randy Savage is ready to throw down at a moment’s notice. A <kanji>riot</kanji> immediately erupts. It’s a battle royal with you and Randy at the epicenter.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself squaring off with Macho Man Randy Savage in the middle of this riot. You have the advantage of having an umbrella, but Randy has the advantage of being himself. Picture yourself getting into a fight with him.

data.meaning_mnemonic: “Don’t <radical>loiter</radical> – <radical>run</radical>, <kanji>Junior</kanji>!” said Indiana Jones Senior to Indiana Jones Junior. They’re escaping from a sticky situation involving Nazis and Junior was just loitering around like a fool. It’s no time to loiter, it’s time to run!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine Sean Connery saying “Don’t loiter – run, Junior!” and you should have a much easier time remembering this phrase if you remember it in his voice.
data.reading_mnemonic: Deciding not to loiter any longer, Indiana Jones <kanji>Junior</kanji> takes his dad’s advice and starts to run. Unfortunately he wasn’t paying attention to where his feet were and he stubbed his <reading>to</reading>e (<ja>と</ja>) on a jagged rock. His toe is in so much pain that he can’t bear to run any longer and gets overtaken by the Nazis that were chasing them.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself as Indiana Jones Junior and this happened to you. Feel the terrible pain of your stubbed toe as Nazis surround you. Hear them jabbering about in German as you clutch your throbbing toe.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>loiter</radical> around the <radical>sun</radical> <radical>temple</radical>, it's likely you'll <kanji>acquire</kanji> something. When you loiter around like that it looks like you're waiting for something, so if someone puts something in your hands and you just happen to acquire it, well, no one can fault you for that.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine loitering around near the sun temple. Maybe you acquire some illegal goods, maybe you just acquire a tan (it is a SUN temple, after all).
data.reading_mnemonic: You managed to <kanji>acquire</kanji> some tobacco, but just as you're about to leave <reading>Toku</reading>gawa (<ja>とく</ja>) Ieyasu comes marching up to you!! Or at least, his ghost does. He stares you dead in the eyes and says, "I didn't found the shogunate for you to acquire illegal goods and kill your body toking on my soil."
data.reading_hint: Your eyes fill with tears under Tokugawa's gaze and you drop everything you acquired to the ground. You bow before him apologizing. You'll never do this again!

data.meaning_mnemonic: It's important to focus <radical>oneself</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> so that one can emerge <kanji>renew</kanji>ed! You can't really go outside in winter without getting cold or sick, so spend winter focusing on YOU.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine sitting in your house all winter, meditating and thinking about how you can renew yourself.
data.reading_mnemonic: Winter ends and, <kanji>renew</kanji>ed, you come out ready to start a new hobby: <reading>ka</reading>yaking (<ja>かい</ja>)! Nothing says renewal like a brand new kayak and sense of purpose in life.
data.reading_hint: Imagine being back in your house in winter. You're thinking about all the kayaking you're gonna do when winter ends. You're even making the movements with your arms, so you'll be a really renewed you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have to <radical>sell</radical> <radical>thread</radical> if you want to <kanji>continue</kanji> to live. You want to make a living don’t you? Make sure you continue to sell that thread every single day!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine selling thread so you can continue living your life.
data.reading_mnemonic: You have to <kanji>continue</kanji> to sell that thread because a Boso<reading>zoku</reading> (<ja>ぞく</ja>) bike gang is forcing you to do it. You see? If you want to continue to live, you have to appease this Bosozoku gang. You better keep selling!
data.reading_hint: Continue selling thread and paying off the Bosozoku. It’s the only way you can continue to survive!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Both a <radical>scooter</radical> and a <radical>car</radical>. These are both things you'll <kanji>take along</kanji> with you.
data.meaning_hint: You can't decide which one you want, so you take along both.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>take along</kanji> the things you need. Anything else, you can do a <reading>ren</reading>tal (<ja>れん</ja>) for.
data.reading_hint: You remembered your scooter and your car, but you forgot something else! You go to the rental shop and do a rental for that item.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sheep</radical> loses its <radical>horns</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> so it picks them up in his <radical>mouth</radical> to take them to a <kanji>morally good</kanji> doctor who is <kanji>good</kanji> enough to attach them back onto his head. This poor sheep lost his horns and now feels quite sad. Sheep don’t have hands, so the sheep had to pick the horns up off the ground with his mouth. An evil doctor would just murder the sheep and steal his horns, so the sheep must find a morally good doctor to reaffix them.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as the good doctor being approached by this forlorn sheep without horns. Hear the clack of the horns together as the sheep drops them out of his mouth onto the ground and lets out a pathetic bleat. “Baa~aa~ah~”
data.reading_mnemonic: Since you are a <kanji>morally good</kanji> doctor, you decide not to murder the sheep and harvest its organs. Instead, as a practitioner of the <kanji>good</kanji> teachings of <reading>Zen</reading> (<ja>ぜん</ja>) Buddhism, you decided to help the sheep out. Your Zen teachings have only increased the power of your healing abilities, so you fix the sheep up in no time.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself using your Zen magic to heal this sheep. Place your hands on the sheep’s horns and imagine returning them to their rightful location on the sheep’s head. Feel the soft wool of the sheep as he bleats in happiness.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you put your <radical>mouth</radical> on a <radical>tree</radical> and try to eat it, you’re probably a <kanji>distressed</kanji> and <kanji>troubled</kanji> individual (unless you’re a woodchuck). You don’t need to eat this tree, you have plenty of food at home. Get your mouth off that tree you distressed child.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as this distressed and troubled person. Taste the taste of sap and bark in your mouth as you nom on the tree with all your might.
data.reading_mnemonic: You thought you were the most <kanji>distressed</kanji> and <kanji>troubled</kanji> person in this situation, but then you look up and see a very equally distressed and troubled <reading>con</reading>dor (<ja>こん</ja>). The tree you've been mouthing is its home. And now you've slobbered all over it, ruining this condor's day.
data.reading_hint: Picture a very distressed condor watching you munch your mouth all over its tree house. You've made a condor enemy this day.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you put a <radical>thread</radical> in the middle of a <radical>kiss</radical>, you’re going to <kanji>entangle</kanji> it. Things can get pretty messy in a kiss, so adding a thread to the mix will definitely entangle it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to kiss someone with a piece of thread between your lips. Feel the thread getting all entangled between the two of you as you lock lips. It’s really detracting from the experience.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is your first kiss ever so getting a thread to <kanji>entangle</kanji> between your lips was really bad <reading>luck</reading> (<ja>らく</ja>). The person you were trying to kiss got really grossed out by the thread and tried to push you away but was so entangled with the thread that they were unable. Bad luck indeed.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself being tied to someone by the tongue with thread. You can’t escape, and you can’t believe your bad luck. Feel the thread tugging on your tongue as you try to get yourself untangled.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>compare</radical> radical and the <kanji>compare</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Huzzah!
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Compare</kanji> a <reading>he</reading>ro (<ja>ひ</ja>) to a normal person. The hero is obviously more exciting and influential on society. If you compare a hero with a normal person, the hero will always be superior.
data.reading_hint: Try to compare yourself with a hero. What sets them apart from you when you compare them to you? Muscles? Superpowers? Spandex?

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>flood</radical> and a <radical>fire</radical>! At the same time? This is a <kanji>disaster</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a disaster so bad that there are floods AND fires. That's too much!
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>disaster</kanji> was caused by your <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>)! It's malfunctioning, running around leaking large amounts of water and breathing fire. I guess you didn't work out all the kinks before you let it roam wild.
data.reading_hint: You better figure out a way to stop your cyborg from causing more disasters like this. Fix it now, or you're gonna be in big trouble.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drunkard</radical> is the kind of <radical>person</radical> who would <radical>poop</radical> two times under a <radical>tree</radical> before using a <kanji>machine</kanji> toilet. There’s a perfectly good outhouse with a machine toilet right there, but this drunkard is so drunk that he decides to poop under the tree instead. And not only does he poop once, he poops twice.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this drunkard, squatting down under the tree to poop. You can smell the poop and a faint stench of alcohol in the air. How could he not have realized that there was a portable machine toilet right there?
data.reading_mnemonic: Oh, I see – the door to the outhouse with the machine toilet is locked, and the drunkard doesn’t have the <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>). If he had a <kanji>machine</kanji> like a jackhammer, or a circular saw, or some other heavy duty machine, he might be able to get in without a key, but since he has none of those or a key, he’s reduced to pooping under the tree instead.
data.reading_hint: Listen to the drunkard grumbling about the lack of a key as he poops under the tree. He doesn’t sound happy, and every time he stresses to push out the poop, his voice fluctuates. Imagine hearing this in your mind and being a wee bit disgusted.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Sitting on the <radical>lid</radical> of a toilet, an <radical>explosion</radical> of <radical>poop</radical> erupts out, getting feces on your <radical>cross</radical> necklace and a large <kanji>percent</kanji> of your clothing. You were just trying to chill out, sitting on the lid of the toilet, and an explosion of poop just flew out the toilet bowl. Now you have poop all over you, like ninety-nine percent of your body is covered in poop. Even your cross necklace.
data.meaning_hint: This feels disgusting. Imagine yourself being covered in poop. Feel the warm smelly sludge covering your body as the abysmal aroma wafts up into your nostrils. You’re nearly one hundred percent covered in poop.
data.reading_mnemonic: You’re emotionally scarred, so you need to eat your comfort food in order to calm yourself down. Your comfort food is <reading>Ritz</reading> (<ja>りつ</ja>) crackers, so you clean one hundred <kanji>percent</kanji> of the poop off you so your body is now zero percent covered by poop, and you start to devour a box of Ritz crackers.
data.reading_hint: Now that the percent of your body covered in poop has reached zero, you can comfortably eat. Imagine yourself eating these Ritz crackers as you slowly start to feel better about life. Taste their buttery crispness as they crumble in your mouth.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>fly</radical> radical and the <kanji>fly</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Awesome!
data.reading_mnemonic: When you <kanji>fly</kanji>, you generate a lot of <reading>he</reading>at (<ja>ひ</ja>) because you’re moving so fast through the atmosphere. Normally this heat would be a nuisance, but you’re a superhero so it doesn’t bother you. This is actually the reason you’re able to fly – you’re a superhero and super resistant to heat.
data.reading_hint: You’re flying through the air super fast. Feel the air rushing past you as heat builds up all over your body from rocketing through the air so fast.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You slip off the <radical>roof</radical>, your <radical>life</radical> flashes before your eyes, and you smash your <radical>mouth</radical> on the ground causing some serious <kanji>damage</kanji>. Oof, this is a really bad <kanji>injury</kanji>, you fell all the way off the roof and onto your mouth.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine that moment as you fall off the roof. In slow motion you can see the roof moving away, you see yourself as a little kid, a teen, an adult, then BAM you've injured your mouth. Ow ow ow!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you try to assess the <kanji>damage</kanji>, you hear someone shout, "<reading>Guy</reading> (<ja>がい</ja>), hey, you okay, guy?" They run up to you, but your mouth is too <kanji>damage</kanji>d, you can't respond. "Okay guy, I'm gonna call you Guy now. Let's get you to the hospital."
data.reading_hint: No matter how much you try to wave your hands and gesture, they keep calling you Guy. It's really annoying, actually, because you aren't a guy and you aren't Guy either. But your mouth is too damaged for you to tell him.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Regardless of whether or not you wear a <radical>hat</radical> while you <radical>jackhammer</radical>, you’re going to have a <kanji>surplus</kanji> of noise. Jackhammers are loud, and your hat is doing nothing to dampen the racket. There’s a surplus of commotion coming from the jackhammer and onlookers are not amused.
data.meaning_hint: The hat you’re wearing is ridiculous, giving you a surplus of bad style. Imagine a bunch of people scowling at you, not only because of your crazy hat, but because of the annoying sound of the jackhammer. Hear the obnoxious noise around you as the jackhammer rattles your bones.
data.reading_mnemonic: One of the people walking by is the owner of a push cart <reading>yo</reading>-yo (<ja>よ</ja>) stand. Having a <kanji>surplus</kanji> of yo-yos, he starts throwing them at you. This makes you stop using the jackhammer as you need both hands to fend off the yo-yo barrage.
data.reading_hint: Your hat is doing little to defend you from the onslaught of yo-yos being tossed at you. Feel the yo-yos hitting your body and listen to them roll away after striking you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Chinese</radical> <radical>turkey</radical> is <kanji>difficult</kanji> to find because they are so rare. Chinese turkeys are the rarest variety of turkey, so naturally, finding one is exceedingly difficult.
data.meaning_hint: Try and picture a Chinese turkey in your brain. Now imagine yourself trying to catch it, but you just can’t. It’s too difficult. The Chinese turkey is too elusive.
data.reading_mnemonic: Do you know the actual reason Chinese turkeys are so <kanji>difficult</kanji> to find? Do you know how many Chinese turkeys there are in the world? <reading>None</reading> (<ja>なん</ja>). They don’t exist. How many Chinese turkeys are there? None.
data.reading_hint: So this is why you had such a difficult time finding and catching one – there were none to be caught. Imagine the sadness you felt when you realized that there were no Chinese turkeys to catch and that none exist in this world.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> moving in one <radical>direction</radical> will <kanji>obstruct</kanji> any other women coming from the other direction. Women are very stubborn, so when a woman decides she is going one direction, she will obstruct anything from getting past her or changing her course.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this woman, obstructing your path. She’s fuming and furious and won’t let anyone past her. Imagine how angry she looks and how terrified you are of her. It’s scary.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this woman decided to <kanji>obstruct</kanji> the path here, you need to figure out how to get past. Probably the best idea is to throw a <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball at her. Bowling balls are heavy, so that will be sure to get her out of the way. Just throw a bowling ball in her direction.
data.reading_hint: Now imagine that you are the woman. Feel the bowling ball hit you in the stomach as it crushes your ribs and knocks you back. Bowling balls hurt.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>spirit</radical> loses its <radical>skin</radical> as a part of the damages it <kanji>incur</kanji>s after death.
data.meaning_hint: Some spirits get mad when they lose their skin, and this makes them incur their wrath on the living humans that still have skin.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you <kanji>incur</kanji> the wrath of an angry spirit, you'll feel your skin <reading>hea</reading>t (<ja>ひ</ja>) up.
data.reading_hint: It feels like your skin is cooking! You're turning red. The spirit is trying to incur the same type of skin damage it had done to it by super-heating your skin! Oww owww!

data.meaning_mnemonic: In <radical>spirit</radical> <radical>valley</radical>, spirits are <kanji>abundant</kanji>. Hence the name. Spirit valley has over two billion spirits floating in it.
data.meaning_hint: Just picture those forest spirits from that famous anime film. The woods are full of them. An abundant valley of spirits.
data.reading_mnemonic: In spirit valley, it's not just spirits that are <kanji>abundant</kanji>. There is an abundance of <reading>you</reading>ths (<ja>ゆう</ja>) as well.
data.reading_hint: Imagine an abundant number of spirits and youths hanging out, drinking microbrews and eating avocado toast. Spirit Valley is a weird place.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Rain</radical> causes a <radical>landslide</radical> that causes an <kanji>earthquake</kanji>!!! The earth doesn't just slide, it <kanji>shake</kanji>s and <kanji>quake</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this happening in real time. First it starts to rain really hard, then the ground starts to shift and run, then everything is shaking and quaking so violently it's an earthquake!
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>earthquake</kanji> shakes you so violently that you fall over, banging your <reading>shin</reading> (<ja>しん</ja>) on the coffee table. The edge of the coffee table is very sharp, so it cuts into your shin pretty badly.
data.reading_hint: You grab your shin, but the earthquake shakes the coffee table toward you to hit your shin yet again! Ow ow ow stop!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have <radical>nine</radical> <radical>flag</radical>s. With these nine flags you take them one by one and put them up your <kanji>butt</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine taking these nine flags... count 'em... and putting them up your butt. With each one that's up there it gets harder and harder to fit the next one in.
data.reading_mnemonic: Now that you have nine flags inside your <kanji>butt</kanji>, you have to get them out. But, you don't know how to. So you ask <reading>Siri</reading> (<ja>しり</ja>), "how do I get nine flags out of my butt?"
data.reading_hint: In your head, doing the Siri voice, come up with an answer for your nine flags in the butt predicament.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>flag</radical> stuck in the ground with a little bit of <radical>fur</radical> coming out from it and on closer inspection you realize it’s actually a <kanji>tail</kanji>. Someone stuck a flag into some sort of animal, pushing it under the ground. All that’s visible now is some fur and part of the tail.
data.meaning_hint: What kind of animal could it be? You start to feel the soft fur with your hand and then the stench of death hits your nostrils. Ew.
data.reading_mnemonic: You try to pull the flag out of the ground and hear a rumbling buzzing sound. At the end of the flagpole you see a huge <reading>bee</reading>hive (<ja>び</ja>)! These bees made their home under the <kanji>tail</kanji>! Maybe that’s why the flag was sticking in it… to warn people. Oops.
data.reading_hint: See the bees swarming out from around the tail and toward your face. Run! Run before there’s nothing left of you but your own tail!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under a <radical>tree</radical> a <radical>drunkard</radical> sits with <radical>twenty</radical> little <kanji>contraptions</kanji>. There's little electronic ones, little bopping ones, little walking ones... twenty of them.
data.meaning_hint: Can you even imagine twenty completely unique contraptions? Why don't you try, just for fun.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to know what these <kanji>contraptions</kanji> are for, so you ask. The drunkard says, "These are <reading>ka</reading>yak (<ja>かい</ja>) contraptions *urp* they're for your uh *blarp* kayak... things."
data.reading_hint: "Kayak contraptions" is pretty vague, but you do have a kayak, so you're tempted anyway. If only you could figure out what each contraption did so you could justify buying some.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take a <radical>stone</radical> to the <radical>forehead</radical> of a <radical>turkey</radical>. It is <kanji>certain</kanji> that you will damage it.
data.meaning_hint: Try hitting a sponge on a turkey's forehead. Not certain. Now a stone. <kanji>Certain</kanji>.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're killing this turkey, and you need to make sure he's dead for <kanji>certain</kanji>. The reason you need to make sure this turkey is dead is because of the <reading>cock</reading> (<ja>かく</ja>) in your life. Male chickens get really jealous when turkeys are around.
data.reading_hint: As you smash the stone into the turkey's forehead, yell out "This is for you, my cock! THIS IS FOR YOU!" Your cock lover watches from the shadows.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>woman</radical> sees the <radical>Mona Lisa</radical>, she feels a strong feeling of <kanji>dislike</kanji>. All women dislike the Mona Lisa because of how much attention she gets.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself feeling this strong dislike towards the Mona Lisa. She gets all the attention and you get none. It’s not fair and you’re upset.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>dislike</kanji> the Mona Lisa so much you hire <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai to cut her up.
data.reading_hint: Ken walks slowly toward the Mona Lisa, dislike shines in his eyes, but then! He falls for her too. No! Ken, destroy her!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> with the <radical>old</radical> <radical>mouth</radical> is the one who has said many things. That makes them different from everyone, an <kanji>individual</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine that leader's old mouth saying things that make the old man stand apart from the others. They are individual from everyone else.
data.reading_mnemonic: As an <kanji>individual</kanji>, one must teach all the <ja><reading>子</reading></ja>s (<ja>こ</ja>) their way. Their individual way.
data.reading_hint: "You must be your own individual. Don't be a sheeple," he says to the <ja>子</ja>s.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> under a <radical>cliff</radical> is going to be under a lot of <kanji>pressure</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being down there with all that dirt. Imagine feeling the pressure closing in around you. It's so hard to breathe... h... help!
data.reading_mnemonic: The dirt being crushed under this <kanji>pressure</kanji> can't help but react by sneezing out, "<reading>Achoo</reading> (<ja>あつ</ja>)!" This sneeze-inducing pressure probably has something to do with where earthquakes come from.
data.reading_hint: Imagine you're the dirt being pressed from every direction, the pressure so strong, and it squeezes an ACHOO right out of you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>narwhal</radical> sticks a <radical>stick</radical> into the <radical>dirt</radical> to see what might <kanji>exist</kanji> underneath it. Narwhals live in the sea, you see. So they're convinced nothing can exist anywhere else.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine seeing a narwhal sticking a stick, and maybe even its horn too, into the dirt on land. It needs to know if life exists outside of the ocean for sure.
data.reading_mnemonic: The narwhal can't find anything but it can't stop thinking about what could <kanji>exist</kanji> outside of its world. It pulls out a <reading>xy</reading>lophone (<ja>ざい</ja>) and starts tapping the keys with its horn. It plays a sad song about the meaning of life and whether existence is worth it.
data.reading_hint: Hear the plinky plink of the xylophone and think about what exists in this world. It's a sad song, you realize.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>net</radical> is upon your <radical>forehead</radical> in the <radical>evening</radical>. These appear on your head at night whenever you are having a <kanji>dream</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Watch yourself sleeping. Then, a net of flowers appear on your forehead as you start to dream.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>dream</kanji> about cows saying "<reading>moo</reading> (<ja>む</ja>), moo, moo!"
data.reading_hint: While still dreaming, you say "moo" out loud too. "Moooo!"

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stand</radical> on the <radical>Cliff</radical> of <radical>Life</radical> and <kanji>give birth</kanji> to a child. Oh no! You’re standing too close to the edge of the Cliff of Life! The baby falls off the cliff right after you give birth to it!
data.meaning_hint: The baby is falling off the cliff! Imagine the sheer terror you feel as the baby plummets to the ground below.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>give birth</kanji>, and now this happens. Such bad luck. But wait! What's that sound? Sleigh bells? Could it be?! It's <reading>San</reading>ta-san (<ja>さん</ja>)! He caught your baby!
data.reading_hint: Oh Santa-san. You're always here for me when I need you most. Even when I'm giving birth to your child.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Someone stabbed the <radical>leader</radical> <radical>mole</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical> to <kanji>overthrow</kanji> it. Now there is a new mole leader. Because that's what happens when you overthrow someone—someone else needs to take over. In this case, a vengeful mole.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a mole sneaking up behind the leader mole and stabbing him with a knife. This type of overthrowing of leadership feels familiar to you. Maybe this has happened before in the past?
data.reading_mnemonic: Where do leaders get <kanji>overthrow</kanji>n the most? In <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. Just think back in Japanese history, back when everyone was at war with one another. People were taking over and getting overthrown and then that guy gets overthrown and then THAT guy gets overthrown. Basically, it used to be hard to stay a leader in <ja>とうきょう</ja>.
data.reading_hint: Picture this like an exaggerated reenactment on the History channel. Leader after leader of <ja>とうきょう</ja> gets overthrown and replaced with the next guy. It never stops. (Until the end of the Edo period, I guess.)

data.meaning_mnemonic: Wash your<radical>self</radical> with a <radical>big</radical> bar of soap if you're <kanji>stinking</kanji> everything up.
data.meaning_hint: Seriously. If you or someone else is stinking to high heaven, embrace a big bar of self care.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're <kanji>stinking</kanji> up the room because you spent your day rolling in <ja><reading>草</reading></ja> (<ja>くさ</ja>). And based on this particular stench, I'd say an animal left something in that <ja>草</ja> too...
data.reading_hint: Imagine trying to use a big bar of soap on yourself to get the stinky <ja>草</ja> off. But it's not working... the <ja>草</ja> stink is SO STRONG!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Hanging off the edge of a <radical>cliff</radical> is a <radical>sun</radical> worshipping <radical>child</radical> with a <kanji>thick</kanji> unibrow. Hanging off the cliff, the child cries at the sun for cursing him to this cruel fate. Even the thickness of his unibrow is not enough to give the child the strength to pull himself back up.
data.meaning_hint: I mean, this unibrow is really, really thick. So thick it doesn’t even look real. But it is. It’s really real and really thick.
data.reading_mnemonic: The child's <kanji>thick</kanji> unibrow can't wait any longer and gives up. It hops off the child's face and says, "Hey dude, I'll be <reading>at Sue's</reading> (<ja>あつ</ja>). She'll appreciate my thick, luxuriousness more than a weakling like you.
data.reading_hint: I guess if you want to go see that thick, beautiful unibrow you'll have to go see it at Sue's now. What's that? Oh, don't worry about the child. It uh. It's probably at Sue's too! Maybe... (or dead).

data.meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>ground</radical>, holding a <radical>brush</radical>, is the <radical>woman</radical> you call your <kanji>wife</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You're standing above your wife, trying to figure out what she's making with her brush on the ground. If you have a real wife in real life, picture her doing this right now.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>wife</kanji> is drawing your <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>) on the ground. Oh no... now your wife is making kissy faces at the cyborg drawing.
data.reading_hint: Okay, so your wife may be in love with the cyborg monstrosity you created a while ago. This could become a problem.

data.meaning_mnemonic: What you <radical>say</radical> is <radical>righteousness</radical>, at least that's what you believe. You keep talking and saying these things, and you don't listen to anyone else's words. This is your style of <kanji>deliberation</kanji> and <kanji>discussion</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself in a deliberation with some other people. They think what they're saying is right, and it drives you mad. Then you realize that you're doing the same thing.
data.reading_mnemonic: What are you in <kanji>deliberation</kanji> about? Whether or not to send some poor soul to the <reading>gui</reading>llotine (<ja>ぎ</ja>). "I think he should go," you say. "I don't think he should," says another. This <kanji>deliberation</kanji> is going nowhere...
data.reading_hint: Imagine how the deliberation concludes. Then, at the end, someone says "This deliberation is over! We have decided to _________" (in regards to the guillotine).

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>animal</radical> kingdom, a <radical>snake</radical> is the most likely to commit a <kanji>crime</kanji>. Remember the Garden of Eden? The snake was the bad guy. Ever since then, snakes are the animal most known for committing crimes.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a snake as a hardened criminal. See this snake with many prison tattoos and muscles from working out in his jail cell. Hear the snake hissing as it slithers about to commit yet another crime.
data.reading_mnemonic: This snake has evaded the law for too long. It’s time for a true hero to put an end to its <kanji>crime</kanji> spree. Enter <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo. Han Solo is the only man strong and brave enough to put an end to this snake and his crime filled ways.
data.reading_hint: Now see Han Solo doing battle with the snake (cue Star Wars music). The snake hisses and lunges at Han, but Han shoots the snake and it’s incapacitated. Smell the smell of scorched snake flesh in your nose.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Put a <radical>net</radical> around a <radical>criminal</radical> to show their <kanji>guilt</kanji>. Criminals look like anyone else on the street, so you decide to tie them in nets to make sure people know who they're dealing with.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine throwing a net around someone you think, no, you know is guilty of doing something bad to you. It feels pretty nice.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>guilt</kanji> shows on the criminal's face. They smile, shrug, and pull a stolen <reading>xy</reading>lophone (<ja>ざい</ja>) out of their back pocket.
data.reading_hint: Woah! The xylophone is huge, how did they... well whatever, you definitely have proof that they're guilty now and the cops should be here any minute to take your criminal catch.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If there is a <radical>building</radical> in the <radical>direction</radical> you want to go it will <kanji>prevent</kanji> you from going any further. Like, come on kid, you think you can just walk right through a building? Don't make me laugh!
data.meaning_hint: There's a building right there. Try to go that direction. Oh, did the building prevent you? Told you so.
data.reading_mnemonic: The building is <kanji>prevent</kanji>ing you from going the right direction, so you pull a <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball out of your bag, aim, and bowl the building over. The building, and all the ones around it, go tumbling down. But now the rubble is preventing you from going further.
data.reading_hint: Your bowling antics are now preventing a bunch of people from going the directions they want to go. Nice job.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>hole</radical> radical and the <kanji>hole</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Spectacular!
data.reading_mnemonic: <reading>Ana</reading> (<ja>あな</ja>) fell into a <kanji>hole</kanji>. Laugh at Ana and her unfortunate misfortune of having fallen into a hole like a ninny. Haha, Ana – you’re stupid and clumsy!
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself laughing at Ana while you point at her, continuing to jeer as Ana struggles to escape the hole. You’d help Ana out of the hole, but you’re too busy laughing at her.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical>, throwing your <radical>hat</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> in front of the <radical>bookshelf</radical>, "I have a <kanji>theory</kanji>!" All this reading and thinking has finally given you a wonderful idea, a theory you think might solve all of your problems!
data.meaning_hint: This theory you've thought of is great, it's going to change everything!
data.reading_mnemonic: "What is your theory, <reading>Ron</reading> (<ja>ろん</ja>)?" asks Hermione. You're Ron Weasley, and you just came up with a theory that you think will help you stop Voldemort.
data.reading_hint: "Ron? Ron, what's your theory? What's your theory, Ron?" Hermione asks over and over. But you freeze. You don't remember who you are. "Hermione, I have a theory that I was just a person learning Japanese, and not a magical boy at all." "Shut up Ron, that's a stupid theory," she replies.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Tying a <radical>thread</radical> to a <radical>tombstone</radical> each year will help you <kanji>manage</kanji> the <kanji>passage of time</kanji>. That way you’ll know how many years it has been, since you’ll have one thread for each year to count.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself coming back to the same tombstone each passing year and tying a new thread to it. You're trying to manage these feelings by keeping track of how much time passes.
data.reading_mnemonic: Dealing with the <kanji>passage of time</kanji> can be tough, so after you tie the thread to the tombstone, each year you eat a piece of <reading>ca</reading>ke (<ja>けい</ja>). You already eat cake to mark the passage of time on your birthday, so why not here as well?
data.reading_hint: Maybe this is your future tombstone, and eating cake each year is a preemptive celebration of your death day! Ooh, what a spooky theory.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Is there a <radical>reason</radical> you're in the <radical>bamboo</radical> grove? Why yes there is. It's so you can get yourself some bamboo and make a <kanji>flute</kanji> out of it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself cutting down some bamboo, thinking "this is the reason I'm here, I need a flute, asap!" There is no other reason to be here besides this.
data.reading_mnemonic: You cut down the bamboo and whittle a <kanji>flute</kanji>. You start playing a song. You know the reason why. An alien spacecraft comes flying down and drops a box full of alien <reading>tech</reading> (<ja>てき</ja>) in front of you.
data.reading_hint: You've done what you came to do. You summoned an alien craft with your bamboo flute, gaining some alien tech in the process. Open up the box to see what tech awaits you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>history</radical> radical and the <kanji>history</kanji> kanji are the same.
data.meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>History</kanji> was full of famous <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>). Sure there are people and stuff, but historical sheep are where it's at. There's the famous sheep samurai, the death sheep who works for the yakuza, just tons!
data.reading_hint: Look at a history book, behind each of those humans was a sheep, changing the world as we know it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Seeing a <radical>mohawk</radical> in the <radical>winter</radical> means the <kanji>enemy</kanji> is nearby. You are from the dreadlock tribe and the mohawk tribe is your enemy. You’re deep in the heart of battle and winter has fallen. Now is the time to take out the enemy.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself holed up in a winter encampment, waiting to strike at the mohawk wearing enemies. Feel the cold around you as you scan the horizon for mohawks.
data.reading_mnemonic: You’re kind of a <reading>techie</reading> (<ja>てき</ja>), so you have an advantage over your <kanji>enemy</kanji>. You’re armed with night vision goggles and other cool tech gear as well. Being a techie certainly has its advantages.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself all teched out like the techie you are. Hear the beeps and boops of all the technology you have at your disposal as you search for more mohawk enemies.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>tsunami</radical> that's <radical>simultaneous</radical> (with another tsunami, I assume) and you know the world is about to <kanji>come to an end</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a tsunami simultaneously happening as the world comes to an end. Oh no, isn't there any way to stop this!?
data.reading_mnemonic: Just as the world is about to <kanji>come to an end</kanji>, your <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>) appears and blocks it with its cyborg body!
data.reading_hint: So the world won't come to an end this one time, thanks to the cyborg you made. Though it doesn't look very good. The cyborg is beaten up and full of water. This might be the end for it...

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Women</radical> who get together to talk about <radical>grain</radical>s are a <kanji>committee</kanji>. They're the Committee of Women for Grains (tm tm tm). What does this committee discuss, you wonder.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine what this committee of women could be coming together to discuss. Aren't grains just grains? Why do they need a whole committee?
data.reading_mnemonic: Well, grains need a <kanji>committee</kanji> because the <reading>ea</reading>gles (<ja>い</ja>) have been eating them all. The women know this, so they're meeting and trying to come up with a way to stop these pesky eagles from eating all the grains and leaving none for the humans.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a committee of women standing together in a field of grain, watching eagles swooping around. They take notes and mutter to one another about their options.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If there’s <radical>grass</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> and <radical>fins</radical> in your <radical>hand</radical>, you need to <kanji>raise</kanji> that hand up to the sky. You’re in the middle of a fisherman’s ritual, which can only be performed on grassy ground. You take fish fins from the previous year, and raise them up to the sky in order to ensure a good fishing harvest.
data.meaning_hint: Feel the grass in your toes and the fins in your hand as you raise them up to the sky. See the sun glistening off the fins as you raise them up in the air.
data.reading_mnemonic: This ritual only works in one part of the world however. It absolutely must be performed in Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (<ja>きょ</ja>). The way Little Kyoto lines up with the sun and the sky and all that astrological junk makes it the best place for you to <kanji>raise</kanji> fish fins up in the air.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself going through the same process as before, only this time imagine yourself in Little Kyoto. Little Kyoto is really little, so make sure you're in the right spot.

data.meaning_mnemonic: "I'll cut that baby in <radical>half</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical> if you don't figure out custody," says the <kanji>judge</kanji>. Ah, the oldest judge trick in the book.
data.meaning_hint: Since you two can't make a decision on who gets custody of the baby, the judge now has to step in and judge for you. Will you figure it out for yourself, or let the baby get cut in half? What an effective judge.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>judge</kanji> is <reading>Han</reading> (<ja>はん</ja>) Solo, so you know he's not going to back down.
data.reading_hint: Han Solo the judge isn't a bad person... but he isn't so good either. He'll cut that baby in half if you don't figure things out. That's the kind of judge Han Solo is.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>life</radical> is being cut off (that's why it looks like that) by a <radical>towel</radical>, which you wrapped around the wound where this <radical>knife</radical> went in. This towel is now <kanji>control</kanji>ling whether you live or die. The complex <kanji>system</kanji> of your life is wrapped up in there, and you don't want it spilling out.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine trying to control your blood loss to save your life with just a towel. You're squeezing as tight as you can.
data.reading_mnemonic: The knife person is coming back to take your life, but you take <kanji>control</kanji> of your own destiny, pull your <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>) out, and slice them in half!
data.reading_hint: Your saber (and towel) have helped you control your own destiny. You did it! And now you need to get this system that is your guts stitched back up.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You use a special <radical>spear</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> to give yourself the <radical>power</radical> to do all of your <kanji>task</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: It's hard to get a task done in winter. That's why you have this spear to power and motivate you.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>task</kanji> is to spear this cow. "<reading>Moo</reading> (<ja>む</ja>)!" it yells at you and runs away. You need to make dinner though... that's your task, so you better catch up to that cow and put an end to its mooing.
data.reading_hint: The moo haunts you as you finish your task. Luckily this spear is helping you keep going even though this task is really difficult.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tree</radical> is growing out of a <radical>top hat</radical> you need to <kanji>inspect</kanji> it to find out why and how this happened. You should probably <kanji>investigate</kanji> the area too. I mean, how could a tree grow out of a top hat anyway? Seems suspicious.
data.meaning_hint: Inspect the tree. Inspect the top hat. Did you find anything?
data.reading_mnemonic: In the middle of your <kanji>inspection</kanji> you realize you need to <reading>saw</reading> (<ja>さ</ja>) the tree open to come to a good conclusion. This seems a bit unnecessary, but no! No! For the sake of this <kanji>investigation</kanji> you must saw the tree in half!
data.reading_hint: Imagine stopping to inspect the tree after each minute of sawing. You'll find out why it's growing out of a top hat! Eventually!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Taking out your <radical>thread</radical>, you sew together the <radical>public</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical>s to make them <kanji>whole</kanji> again.
data.meaning_hint: The world has been in turmoil and the public has been suffering, but it's time to stop splitting our hearts apart and fighting. It's time to be whole again.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once their hearts are <kanji>whole</kanji>, the public's <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>) becomes one!
data.reading_hint: Suddenly people who were fighting for years are crying and holding one another. Their souls recognize each other, they're healed, and the whole nation is finally seeing eye to eye.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>say</radical> a new <radical>weapon</radical> idea out loud, then it will be <kanji>establish</kanji>ed immediately.
data.meaning_hint: Try it out: I want a stabbing weapon with extra weapons that can pop out on the sides. *POOF* You've established a new weapon. And it's been added to the official weapon wiki of the world.
data.reading_mnemonic: Weapons have to be <kanji>establish</kanji>ed in <reading>sets</reading> (<ja>せつ</ja>). So you have to make another one that goes with it. Make them cohesive please.
data.reading_hint: Establish weapons in sets or the people who use them won't be able to match each other.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>next</radical> <radical>shellfish</radical> will be yours, but this shellfish will be mine. These are the <kanji>resources</kanji> we have to share and distribute.
data.meaning_hint: Our resources are based around a system of trading shellfish. It's not that weird, plenty of ancient societies used shellfish as their main resource!
data.reading_mnemonic: You save up all of your <kanji>resources</kanji> so you can buy a <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>). You bring a big sack of your shellfish resources to the market and finally get to pick out that sheep you've had your eyes on for months.
data.reading_hint: Of course you're going to use your resources to get a sheep. You're living in a time when shellfish are used to trade for goods and services!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>tree</radical> lies a <radical>turkey</radical> with a broken <radical>arrow</radical> in it. It doesn't have <kanji>rights</kanji> like humans, so people can just shoot turkeys with arrows and no one is punished.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine if humans didn't have any rights, like this turkey. People could just gun each other down in the street and no one would be punished for it... oh wait. :/
data.reading_mnemonic: "You have <kanji>rights</kanji>, so I won't shoot you like this turkey," says the voice of <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai, from above you in the tree.
data.reading_hint: He jumps down and picks the turkey up, the broken arrow sticking out of its neck. "Turkeys do not have rights, my friend. Just let this one go."

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>cow</radical> tribe is too important to deal with small <kanji>matter</kanji>s and trivial <kanji>affair</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this hoity-toity cow leader who thinks he’s too good for small matters and affairs. See him acting all fancy like he’s better than everyone else. The cow even moos with a fake British accent. How pretentious.
data.reading_mnemonic: All of his <kanji>affair</kanji>s are taken care of by <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai, who he hired as his underling.
data.reading_hint: Picture Ken the samurai scooping poop for the leader of the cows, because that's a matter of poop and state.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is coming for the <radical>cliff</radical> made of <radical>tofu</radical>, but there is a special <kanji>sect</kanji> that protects tofu cliff.
data.meaning_hint: This sect of the tofu-lovers club takes their duties very seriously and they must protect this tofu cliff at all costs.
data.reading_mnemonic: All of the members of the <kanji>sect</kanji> are standing on the cliff, their hands raised, and right as the tsunami is about to collide with them, they shout, "<reading>Ha</reading> (<ja>は</ja>)!" and it's repelled! The tsunami sinks and rolls back out to sea, the tofu cliff is safe!
data.reading_hint:
Oh, do you want to be a member of the tofu sect? HA! Don't make me laugh. If you ask to be a member of a sect, you'll never get in.

Never ask for a sect.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have a scene going on inside your <radical>head</radical>. It is of a pair of <radical>horns</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> atop a <radical>mountain</radical>. No. It is not just one pair of horns. It is many. So many that they create a giant <kanji>hill</kanji> atop the mountain, which is already pretty high.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this hill of horns on top of this mountain. This hill of horns makes it possible for you to get just high enough to touch the top of the sky.
data.reading_mnemonic: How was standing atop this hill of horns on top of a mountain to touch the sky? Eh. It was <reading>oka</reading>y (<ja>おか</ja>), but that's about it.
data.reading_hint: Feel indifferent about this hill of horns on top of the mountain. It's all in your head anyways.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>life</radical> <radical>thread</radical> is an <kanji>element</kanji> essential to all living things. This thread of life joins all things together, providing an essential relationship between all life. This element is all that holds this world together.
data.meaning_hint: Visualize this element of life, interconnecting all living things. Without it, everything would fall apart and into chaos.
data.reading_mnemonic: You need to keep this <kanji>element</kanji> clean, so you make sure to wash it with <reading>so</reading>ap (<ja>そ</ja>) every single day. This turns out to be pretty hard because the element is an invisible thread, but you do your best.
data.reading_hint: Imagine grabbing hold of the element that holds all life together and trying to wash it with soap. It's slippery so you keep dropping it and soap keeps going in your eyes.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>lion</radical> harvesting <radical>rice</radical> uses an <radical>axe</radical> to <kanji>cut off</kanji> the tops of the stalks. The lion is roaming the rice fields using his axe to harvest the rice. He does so by cutting off the part of the rice stalks he needs.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this lion on his hind legs, walking through a rice field. He’s holding an axe in one hand and acting like a human. See him cut off the plants and hear the whoosh of the axe as he cuts.
data.reading_mnemonic: The lion will <kanji>cut off</kanji> rice stalks until <reading>dawn</reading> (<ja>だん</ja>). But at the first light of dawn, it will run and hide in the shade of the trees, cut off from the rice.
data.reading_hint: When dawn comes in Africa (it's a lion, so that's where he is) it gets too hot to be in the sun, so the lion gets cut off from his job of cutting things off.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You should <radical>say</radical> your <radical>peace</radical> before you <kanji>evaluate</kanji> a situation. That way everyone will know where you’re coming from. If you’re honest and say your peace before you evaluate a situation out loud, everyone will know where you stand.
data.meaning_hint: What situation would you like to evaluate? Be sure to say your peace before doing so. Imagine yourself doing this out loud and think of what you would say.
data.reading_mnemonic: While you say your peace, you end up making a really bad pun and you hear somebody say “<reading>Heyo</reading>!” (<ja>ひょう</ja>) You look at the people around you and try to <kanji>evaluate</kanji> who said heyo, but you can’t tell. You start talking again when somebody exclaims “That’s what she said” and another person shouts “Heyo!” once again, but you still can’t evaluate who’s saying these things.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself trying to explain a situation you’re about to evaluate and your audience keeps shouting “Heyo!” every other sentence. Imagine how frustrating that would be. Get angry at your rude audience and how much they shout “Heyo.”

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you use your <radical>fingers</radical> to point when you <radical>compare</radical> things you're really just throwing around <kanji>criticism</kanji>. You should never need to point fingers when you're just comparing things. If you're pointing and picking and being mean, that's criticism.
data.meaning_hint: Some criticism is okay, as long as it's constructive and it helps the person get better. But when you start pointing fingers, it's time to step back and try to not be such a jerk.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you're having trouble not giving out <kanji>criticism</kanji>, just think about how you would react if someone criticized you. You'd feel an embarrassed <reading>he</reading>at (<ja>ひ</ja>) rise throughout your body. That heat will cover your whole face.
data.reading_hint: Before you throw criticism around, imagine that embarrassed heat. You don't want to feel that way, so why would you do it to someone else?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Both a <radical>leader</radical> and a <radical>king</radical> have a <kanji>duty</kanji> to protect their people. A good leader always protects his followers, and a good king always protects his subjects. This is their duty.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself being protected by your king and leader. They don’t really like you, but it is their duty to protect you. See them fighting off evil doers and taking bullets for your sake.
data.reading_mnemonic: You’re the village <reading>nin</reading>compoop (<ja>にん</ja>), but the king and the leader still have a <kanji>duty</kanji> to protect you. Even a nincompoop is important to the kings and leaders of the world.
data.reading_hint: You’re a nincompoop. Even though you’re so nincompoopy, your king and leader still have a duty to protect you. Feel happy and content, despite your nincompoopery.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>tree</radical> with a <radical>squid</radical> on it, so you get closer to <kanji>examine</kanji> it.
data.meaning_hint: As you examine the tree and the squid in it, you think, "Huh, nope still weird." You should examine it further to find out what's going on.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're sticking your face in really, really close to <kanji>examine</kanji> this little squid in the tree when <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai appears behind you. "There you are, squid! Thank you citizen, I've been looking all over for my little chum."
data.reading_hint: Imagine how many trees Ken examined before he found you both. Picture him putting his face really close to each one, then shedding a single tear when he realized this squid wasn't in it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're about to enter a <radical>roof</radical> that has your <radical>number</radical> on it so you can face the <kanji>judge</kanji>. You've been sitting here for what feels like hours, waiting for your number to come up. Finally the time has come—the judge will see you now.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the judge sitting under the roof. Your number is sitting on his big desk, next to the gavel.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>judge</kanji> is not happy with you. He tells you to come closer and when you do, he takes his gavel and hits you in the <reading>shin</reading>s (<ja>しん</ja>). Ouch!
data.reading_hint: You try to ask the judge what his ruling is, but he just hits you on the shins again!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>winter</radical> <radical>tree</radical> is only a winter tree due to a <kanji>clause</kanji> in its tree contract.
data.meaning_hint: The clause states that it cannot be a tree in the summer, because that is the summer tree's territory. Same goes for autumn and spring trees. Go ahead and look at the winter tree's contract, if you want (they're nailed to every tree). There's the clause that says it can only be a tree in the winter.
data.reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>clause</kanji> was written into all trees' contracts by <reading>Jou</reading>rm (<ja>じょう</ja>), the large farmhand.
data.reading_hint: Jourm noticed that the trees were getting too crowded, so he wrote up these clauses and added them to the trees' contracts. Now, the forests are less crowded, thanks to the little clause. Makes sense that a farmhand like Jourm would do this too. The fewer trees, the more farmland. It's good for folks like Jourm.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Young people nowadays have an abnormal (looking) <radical>life</radical>, and they spend their <radical>shellfish</radical> (money) on things I don't like. So I <kanji>blame</kanji> them for everything that's wrong with the world today!
data.meaning_hint: Darn those kids and their vidja games and their rap music. I blame them for everything! If they didn't eat so much avocado toasts I'd be able to have another mansion!
data.reading_mnemonic: Those who <kanji>blame</kanji> everything on the people who live lives they don't recognize also seem to find them <reading>sexy</reading> (<ja>せき</ja>). Which is ridiculous if you think about it. How can you find someone sexy and then also judge everything they do and blame them for things?
data.reading_hint: I dunno, I think there might be a lesson somewhere in this mnemonic, but you'll have to look really hard to see it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You only have a <radical>few</radical> <radical>eye</radical>s so you need to <kanji>conserve</kanji> what's left.
data.meaning_hint: You only have like, three eyes left. If you conserve them .
data.reading_mnemonic: You're trying to <kanji>conserve</kanji> your eyes, when the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) marches by. He stops, sees you, and demands you give him your remaining eyes! But sir, I'm conserving what little I have left!
data.reading_hint: The Shougun stares down at you, eyes blazing, and you hand over all but one of your eyes. Now you really have to conserve, or you'll be blind. Thanks Shougun. I bet he has plenty of eyes, he didn't need yours.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> <radical>mask</radical> is a mask which, when put on, will greatly <kanji>increase</kanji> the amount of dirt.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine putting it on, and suddenly the dirt around you increases by quite a bit.
data.reading_mnemonic: Use the dirt mask to <kanji>increase</kanji> the dirt around you. The <radical>zo</radical>mbies (<ja>ぞう</ja>) are trying to escape, so you just keep increasing the dirt on top of them so they can't get out.
data.reading_hint: Zombie hands keep coming out of the ground, but as long as you wear the mask and increase the dirt on top of them, they won't be able to escape their earthly prison.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>guard</radical> is at your door and wants some of your <radical>grain</radical>s. This is the <kanji>tax</kanji> you pay for living in this town. Back in the day, grains were used like currency, so it makes sense that there was a grain tax in the olden days.
data.meaning_hint: Can you imagine a guard coming to your door and demanding you pay your grain tax?
data.reading_mnemonic: You have to pay this <kanji>tax</kanji>, because if you don't the guard will cut you down with his special German saber, a <reading>zei</reading>ber (<ja>ぜい</ja>). "Don't you hear vat I zei? Pay ze tax or I vill zlei you!" he shouts.
data.reading_hint: You don't want to be sliced with the zeiber, so you listen to vat he zei zei zei's and pay the tax.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Angle</radical> your <radical>sword</radical> correctly at a <radical>cow</radical> to <kanji>untie</kanji> it without hurting it. This is actually a pretty tough angle to get your sword, so in order to <kanji>solve</kanji> this cow puzzle you have to be really smart and careful.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the cow looking up at you with her big, brown eyes. She doesn't want to be tied here anymore, so you have to solve this and untie her.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're trying to <kanji>untie</kanji> this cow from the <reading>ka</reading>yak (<ja>かい</ja>) you're both currently in. Some jerk tied the cow to this kayak and sent it toward a waterfall. If you don't <kanji>solve</kanji> this riddle fast, you'll both go with the kayak over the falls!
data.reading_hint: Picture it: you're standing in a kayak with this cow, trying to untie the rope around their neck by getting your sword to cut it at the right angle. You can't hurt the cow or knock over the kayak. Can you solve it in time?!

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Building</radical>s hold <radical>festival</radical>s on special <kanji>occasion</kanji>s.
data.meaning_hint: A festival can't be happening all the time. Then it wouldn't be special, it would just be a party building, so they can only happen on special occasions.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>occasion</kanji> this time is to celebrate your wonderful <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>). It's about time you did something nice for it.
data.reading_hint: Your cyborg has been really great lately. Your wife loves it. It saved the world. It's nice of you to take this occasion to show the cyborg how much it means to you all with a festival.

data.meaning_mnemonic: What people <radical>say</radical> to you will be carved by a <radical>blade</radical> into your <radical>heart</radical>, and the next time you see them, you'll immediately <kanji>recognize</kanji> them.
data.meaning_hint: Sometimes your brain won't recognize someone, but your heart will. That's because what they say draws that blade across your heart and leaves a mark, for better or for worse, forever.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>recognize</kanji> places, names, and even games this way. But the thing that has the most real estate on your heart, the thing you recognize the most, is <reading>Nin</reading>tendo (<ja>にん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: There's just something about Nintendo—you'd recognize them and their games anywhere.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>hat</radical> comes to a <radical>stop</radical>, thinking of a <kanji>plan</kanji>. The hat had been pacing around for a while, trying to think of how to get off the head he's resting upon and back into the house where it's nice and cozy, and came to the sudden realization of a plan. This caused the hat to stop.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a hat walking about on your head, pacing back and forth deep in thought. See the hat stroke its chin in contemplation as it tries to think up a plan to get off your noggin and back inside.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>plan</kanji> that made this hat stop right in its tracks was very simple. First, obtain the <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>) to the house. Then, use the key to get in the front door. How simple!
data.reading_hint: Watch as the hat begins to grin. This plan is so simple it’s sure to work. Now watch as the hat obtains the key and enters the locked door. What sort of mischief will the hat get into once inside?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
data.meaning_hint: If you know the radical, you will know the kanji as well!
data.reading_mnemonic: Such <kanji>righteousness</kanji>! Well, at least according to the king who thinks he's being righteous. His version of righteousness is to send anyone who disagrees with him to the <reading>gui</reading>llotine (<ja>ぎ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: "THIS IS NOT RIGHTEOUSNESS!" you yell, just before the guillotine comes down on your neck.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you try to <radical>say</radical> things with a <radical>knife</radical>, the police will put you in a <radical>net</radical> as your <kanji>penalty</kanji> for breaking the knife laws. You can't just go up to other people and say things with a knife out.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine getting so mad that you use a knife instead of words to say what you're trying to say. A net falls over you and pulls you down. The knife goes flying. This is your penalty for acting like a crazy person.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>penalty</kanji> for breaking the law isn't over. Now that you're stuck in a net, you can't fight back when they hit you with <reading>bats</reading> (<ja>ばつ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: If you don't want to be punished with bats, maybe next time don't use a knife instead of your words.

data.meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> <radical>yoga</radical> is the <radical>correct</radical> way to go through <kanji>birth</kanji>. Birth isn't easy, but people keep telling you that yoga is the right way to prepare and actually do it.
data.meaning_hint: Picture multiple people you know saying you should do yoga if you plan to give birth. It isn't a question of whether you want to, it's the correct way to do it. So you should.
data.reading_mnemonic: To prepare for giving <kanji>birth</kanji> you end up doing so much yoga outside that you get a really deep <reading>tan</reading> (<ja>たん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Hopefully having a tan doesn't make birth harder, since you've worked so hard to do this the correct way with so much yoga.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The light of the <radical>moon</radical> is shining on a <radical>guard</radical> who's been on duty all night. The moon light makes him so warm and comfortable that he forgets where he is and starts to <kanji>undress</kanji>. He thinks he's home! Everyone is going to see him take off his clothes!
data.meaning_hint: Picture a sleepy guard, bathed in moonlight, starting to undress. No! Keep your uniform on guard! Don't undress outside in the middle of the night!
data.reading_mnemonic: You can't seem to get the guard to stop <kanji>undress</kanji>ing so you throw some <reading>darts</reading> (<ja>だつ</ja>) at him. You figure that even if the guard doesn't snap out of this weird sleepy trance, at least you can use the darts to stick his clothes to his body. Then maybe he won't be able to undress anymore.
data.reading_hint: Imagine throwing darts at a guard who's undressing himself. Imagine trying to aim for his pants so they'll be nailed to his body.

data.meaning_mnemonic: While riding on your <radical>scooter</radical>, you grow a <radical>mustache</radical> on top of the <radical>mustache</radical> you already have in order to <kanji>surpass</kanji> the people around you. You're in a scooter race and your mustache is the only thing keeping you in the lead, but someone else has a mustache too! So you grow another mustache to surpass them once again!
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself running on a scooter with a bunch of other people and closing your eyes tight, willing another mustache to sprout out of your face to surpass them all.
data.reading_mnemonic: Suddenly, something else manages to <kanji>surpass</kanji> you all. It's a <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>)! A car with two mustaches is also riding on a scooter and going way faster than you.
data.reading_hint: Watch helplessly as the car surpasses every single one of your scooter. Both of your mustaches droop in shame.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Can you look at the <radical>dirt</radical> and know which <radical>direction</radical> you need to go? Then you might be a <kanji>monk</kanji>. Monks have amazing skills like that. And I'm sure you've seen monks wandering around in lots of media. They don't need maps or smartphones. They just look at the dirt and let the earth guide them to where they need to be.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a monk walking through a large field in the middle of nowhere. He knows where to go, he's not afraid. The dirt will lead him in the right direction.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to know the <kanji>monk</kanji>'s trick so you hide behind him for a while as he walks. Finally the monk stops, looks around, takes out a <reading>bow</reading>ling (<ja>ぼう</ja>) ball and starts bowling in the dirt. The bowling ball rolls off, the monk follows it, and then heads off in that direction.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a monk bowling in the middle of the road. Imagine your shock at how well he handles the ball. Also, imagine how heavy it must be for a monk to carry a bowling ball everywhere!

data.meaning_mnemonic: From the <radical>roof</radical>, an <radical>icicle</radical> falls and hits <radical>wolverine</radical> in the <radical>forehead</radical>, and he has to go over to the <radical>stool</radical> to <kanji>lie down</kanji>. And eventually he goes to <kanji>sleep</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this entire scene. The icicle falls in slow motion from the roof. It hits wolverine right in the middle of his forehead. He goes down. He has to lie down. He has to sleep.
data.reading_mnemonic: While wolverine <kanji>sleep</kanji>s, he makes a horrible <reading>neigh</reading>ing (<ja>ね</ja>) sound. It's like there's a giant horse in his mouth screaming to get out! NEIGH NEIGH!
data.reading_hint: Wolverine might have a concussion that's making him neigh in his sleep. I guess it's good that he's laying down, but I'm pretty sure you're not supposed to sleep... Maybe you should wake him up so the neighing will stop—I mean, so he'll be okay!

data.meaning_mnemonic: It may just be a <radical>roof</radical> over a <radical>bathtub</radical>, but this here is actually a <kanji>Shinto shrine</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: It is indeed just a roof over a bathtub, but I guess spirits inhabit everything according to Shintoism, so there's no reason this bathtub can't be a Shinto shrine too.
data.reading_mnemonic: What god does this <kanji>Shinto shrine</kanji> hold? You see that "It's a-<reading>me-ya</reading>! (Mario!)"
data.reading_hint: It makes sense, the person who says "It's-a-me! (Mario)" is someone who works on bathtubs (and plumbing).

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>kiss</radical> <kanji>each</kanji> of your best pals to show them how much you love and care for them. You kiss each friend right on the mouth.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine kissing each of your best friends on the mouth. Does this make you uncomfortable? Excited? Both? Feel that feeling.
data.reading_mnemonic: Actually, <kanji>each</kanji> of your best pals are of the <reading>cock</reading> (<ja>かく</ja>) variety. By that, I mean they are both roosters. Imagine kissing both of these cocks on their beaks.
data.reading_hint: Kissing the cock beak is kind of a strange experience. Feel the feathers in your hands as you steady the cock to kiss it. Cock-a-doodle-doo!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>cheap</radical> <radical>tree</radical> has a <kanji>plan</kanji>. A plan to stay cheap.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a tree coming up with some elaborate plans to make sure they can spend as little money as possible.
data.reading_mnemonic: The cheap tree's <kanji>plan</kanji> involves only buying <reading>an</reading>chovies (<ja>あん</ja>) and surviving on them. Good exposure to the sun and fresh water is too expensive. The tree plans to save money by eating anchovies.
data.reading_hint: You're not sure about this anchovy plan. Are you cheap enough to choose a life of eating only anchovies?

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>net</radical> needs to be <radical>fix</radical>ed if you want to <kanji>put</kanji> food on the table.
data.meaning_hint: You can't put something in your net if it's broken. Fix it!
data.reading_mnemonic: Once it's fixed, you <kanji>put</kanji> a bunch of <reading>chee</reading>se (<ja>ち</ja>) in the net. You want to catch something that eats cheese, so that you can then put that animal on your dinner table.
data.reading_hint: Imagine putting a bunch of cheese in your now-fixed net. It kinda stinks!

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Dollar</radical>s and <radical>shellfish</radical> are used to pay <kanji>expense</kanji>s and <kanji>cost</kanji>s. Shellfish used to be used as currency, so they're like the coins that go with dollars.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine opening your bank account and looking at all of your monthly expenses. Now drag the little dollar and shellfish icons over to cover all of those costs.
data.reading_mnemonic: What is the biggest <kanji>expense</kanji> and <kanji>cost</kanji>? It's the <reading>hea</reading>t (<ja>ひ</ja>) bill.
data.reading_hint: When you see how expensive your heat is, you feel a heat going through your body too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>helicopter</radical> the <radical>leader</radical> is in has the most <kanji>value</kanji>! He would only choose to fly the very best one, after all. That's why it's worth way more than the others. Actually, any helicopter he flies goes up in value. That's the amazing effect of a good leader.
data.meaning_hint: Can you understand the value of this helicopter? The leader flew it to war and back! So of course it's worth a lot!
data.reading_mnemonic: To further increase the helicopter's <kanji>value</kanji>, the leader bought himself a <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>) and then tied them together. Now it has the value of a helicopter AND a car! Wow!
data.reading_hint: Imagine driving a valuable car with the leader's helicopter on top. Yeah!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>womb</radical> is a <radical>circle</radical> of <radical>power</radical> where a <kanji>force</kanji> of nature is formed. The womb has the power to create life. Life is a force of nature, and the circle of life starts in the womb.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself in the womb. You’re being born into the world. Feel the force and energy of your mother around you. Hear the sound of water as you float about in the womb. Force yourself to breathe the fluid and imagine yourself doing so.
data.reading_mnemonic: Now pretend you are the pregnant woman. You need to <kanji>force</kanji> that baby out of you with such force that the baby comes flying out, so you grab hold of your special <reading>sa</reading>ber (<ja>せい</ja>)! You close your eyes, breathe and feel the force of the saber entering your body. Then the baby is forced right out!
data.reading_hint: As the baby is forced out, you slice with your saber and cut the umbilical cord before the baby is caught in a basket!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> who knows how to use a <radical>bathtub</radical> will have to <kanji>manage</kanji> all the baths for the other Vikings. Vikings aren't so great with bathing... if you can get one Viking to figure it out he has to manage the rest of them.
data.meaning_hint: Picture a Viking trying to manage his Viking friends so they'll use the bathtub properly. He has to manage which people go in when, how hot or cold the water is, and provide all the soap. It's a very important job.
