data.reading_hint: The person you axed cries and tries desperately to find their blood on the axe so they can keep suing you properly. You hold the soap behind your back and cackle.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Be careful what you <radical>say</radical> in <radical>public</radical>, otherwise you might face a <kanji>lawsuit</kanji>. People will sue you for just about anything these days, so you really need to watch what you say in public, otherwise you might find yourself with a lawsuit on your hands.
data.meaning_hint:
Think of all the things you could say in public that could get you stuck dealing with a lawsuit.

Oh my gosh! How dare you think those things?! You're lucky you didn't say them out loud in public, or I'd file a lawsuit against you myself!
data.reading_mnemonic: Any and all <kanji>lawsuit</kanji>s need to be brought before the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>). Oh, you thought you'd get a judge or a jury? Nope, the Shougun decides your fate.
data.reading_hint: You better hope what you said wasn't about the Shougun, or he's really going to use this lawsuit to destroy you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Someone took your <radical>scooter</radical> and used a <radical>brush</radical> and some <radical>water</radical> to take off all the paint, and now you need to <kanji>apprehend</kanji> them!
data.meaning_hint: Not only did they steal your scooter, but they tried to make it look like it wasn't even yours anymore. Now you and all the cops are chasing this dude down on police scooters and you're going to apprehend him!
data.reading_mnemonic: You catch up to the thief and <kanji>apprehend</kanji> him by tying him down with the <reading>tie</reading> (<ja>たい</ja>) from around your neck!
data.reading_hint: It's a really nice tie you use to apprehend him, so even though the scooter thief is struggling and fighting, he can't get away.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>spirit</radical> at your <radical>wedding</radical>. It's there as a <kanji>supplement</kanji> to the guests because not enough people came.
data.meaning_hint: It's weird that you supplemented your wedding guests with a spirit or two, but even if you hadn't invited them, they may have showed up anyway.
data.reading_mnemonic: Along with the spirits to <kanji>supplement</kanji> your wedding guests, you made everyone carry a <reading>hoe</reading> (<ja>ほ</ja>). That way no one had to bring a date, they carry a garden hoe as a supplement and no one feels bad about being dateless. Everyone is!
data.reading_hint: Maybe you should supplement your wedding with other things next time... instead of spirits and garden hoes.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> with a <radical>stick</radical>, a <radical>hook</radical>, and an <radical>arrow</radical> is able to change the <kanji>climate</kanji> and <kanji>weather</kanji>. Not just the type of climate that causes sunny and rainy days though, the political climate too, because they're a political <kanji>candidate</kanji> too.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this leader twirling his stick around with his hook so quickly it changes the actual weather. Then he shoots it into the sky with an arrow, changing the actual climate itself.
data.reading_mnemonic: Who is this <kanji>climate</kanji> and <kanji>weather</kanji>-changing <kanji>candidate</kanji> leader with the hook, stick, and arrow? It's none other than <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>.
data.reading_hint: Ask <ja>こういち</ja> why he's changing the climate. He says more people do their WaniKani reviews when it's raining, so he decided to create climate change to make it more dangerous to go outside. "This way, people will stay indoors and do their WaniKani reviews," he tells you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>lifeguard</radical> will choose a <radical>tree</radical> to <kanji>set up</kanji> the station where he'll <kanji>care</kanji> for the people on the beach and in the water. Trees provide the shade lifeguards need to take care of half-drowned kids and grannies with sand stuck in their bathing suits. That's why they set up their care stations here.
data.meaning_hint: Watch the lifeguard walk around the beach. He needs to pick a nice big tree for his set up, so he can provide the best care possible.
data.reading_mnemonic: You look closer at the <kanji>set up</kanji> and realize the lifeguard is <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>! You know he teaches Japanese but... is <ja>こういち</ja> really qualified to care for people like this?
data.reading_hint:
Imagine <ja>こういち</ja> setting up a care station. You hope you don't get in trouble in the water so you don't have to see how good he is at caring for people.

Hint: when you see the "lifeguard" radical, the reading is probably going to be <ja>こう</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> grows next to a <radical>greenhouse</radical> enclosing an <kanji>imitation</kanji> of the tree. The imitation greenhouse tree wants to be big and impressive like the tree outside, so it does its very best imitation of a real tree.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this greenhouse tree struggle to grow big and strong like the wild tree outside. Hear its leaves shake and timber creak. How cute.
data.reading_mnemonic: The greenhouse tree realizes that its <kanji>imitation</kanji> will never be as good as the real thing. When it realizes this, the tree <reading>mo</reading>ans (<ja>も</ja>) aloud. The tree is still kinda tiny, so the moan isn’t very loud, but it is still pretty strange to witness. Speaking of witnesses, <reading>Bo</reading>bo (<ja>ぼ</ja>) the clown sees this greenhouse tree moaning and decides to take it for his next clown show. Surely this miniature moaning tree can be worked into Bobo's next clown act.
data.reading_hint: Hear the little tree moaning at its pitiful imitation of a real tree. The greenhouse tree sounds very sad and you actually start to feel bad for it. Moan along with the tree in sympathy.

data.meaning_mnemonic: At your <radical>wedding</radical> you use your <radical>fingers</radical> to <kanji>catch</kanji> the wedding rings. And to catch the bouquet. And to catch the rice that everyone is throwing at you, ow, ow, hey stop! Weddings are really more about catching things than they are about whoever is standing across from you.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being at a wedding and getting to catch a ton of things in your fingers.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're having a good time <kanji>catch</kanji>ing things until it's cleanup time and someone throws a <reading>hoe</reading> (<ja>ほ</ja>) at you. First of all, ow again, that was your face. Second, this is your wedding. You aren't supposed to have to hoe it all up. You're supposed to drop everything you caught and leave!
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself grumpily hoeing all the things you couldn't catch, and the dirt under it, and putting it into a big dumpster.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>fish</radical> and <radical>sheep</radical> are very <kanji>fresh</kanji> here. This is a great place to get fresh fish and fresh sheep. I kid you not.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine eating this fresh fish and fresh sheep. It’s the freshest you’ve ever tasted. Taste it on your tongue and experience how fresh it is.
data.reading_mnemonic: This place also serves <kanji>fresh</kanji> <reading>cen</reading>taur (<ja>せん</ja>), but that’s just weird. Centaur is endangered and you don’t believe in eating endangered things. Even if they are incredibly fresh.
data.reading_hint: Can you imagine eating a fresh centaur? How weird would that be? Half of it is human-like, so you’d be like, a half cannibal. Weird, huh?

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>mix</radical> different types of <radical>power</radical> you'll produce something <kanji>effective</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: It doesn't matter what power you mix, because all power is strong. No matter what you use this mixed power on, it will be effective. Imagine some situations where you mix power with power.
data.reading_mnemonic: The most <kanji>effective</kanji> mix of two powers is two <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>s. Take one, mix it with another, and you have something with immeasurable power. You use it to attack that animal-like creature. It's super effective!
data.reading_hint: <ja>こういち</ja>s punch attack was super effective against that Pikurchort.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>mantis</radical> sitting on a <radical>flag</radical> and you know for a fact that it does not <kanji>belong</kanji> there. Insects should be in trees and on the ground. Not on flags. Insects belong in the wild!
data.meaning_hint: Look at that mantis, pretending it belongs here. What are you gonna do about it?
data.reading_mnemonic: Luckily for you, and unluckily for this mantis who doesn't <kanji>belong</kanji> on your flag, you're a Boso<reading>zoku</reading> (<ja>ぞく</ja>) bike gang member, and you don't take crap from nobody. You climb the flagpole, punch the mantis and yell, "YOU DON'T BELONG HERE!"
data.reading_hint: Your Bosozoku life has prepared you for this moment. Those who don't belong, shall be punished, you think to yourself.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you could just get your <radical>soul</radical> to open the <radical>window</radical> to <radical>shellfish</radical>, you'll grow <kanji>accustomed</kanji> to them sooner or later! I know shellfish are a bit of an acquired taste, but if you don't open that window, you'll never like them!
data.meaning_hint: Close your eyes and picture your soul. Now your soul is opening a little window inside of you that is the perfect size for shellfish of all kinds. Hopefully with exposure and acceptance you'll grow accustomed to them.
data.reading_mnemonic: You'll need to become <kanji>accustomed</kanji> to eating shellfish if you want to grow up big and strong like Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>). He didn't have shellfish growing up either you know, he had to grow accustomed to their taste too, but look how successful he was!
data.reading_hint: Force yourself to get accustomed to shellfish like Genghis Khan, then maybe you'll rule most of the planet someday.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Music</radical> <radical>beans</radical> make farts <kanji>plentiful</kanji>. And lucky for you, music beans themselves are also plentiful, so you can eat plenty of them to power your musical bean toots.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine dancing to your own plentiful bean music as you gorge on beans.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your music bean farts are too <kanji>plentiful</kanji> to leave your <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>). If you tried to leave your home you'd definitely fart all over people outside, so you keep your plentiful farts to yourself.
data.reading_hint: Be polite! Keep your plentiful farts at home.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> hits these <radical>flowers</radical> they'll <radical>both</radical> become <kanji>full</kanji> of water. Tsunamis carry a lot of water, definitely enough to make both of these flowers full.
data.meaning_hint: Picture both of these little flowers, happily swaying in the breeze. Then the tsunami comes, leaves, and you look back and their little cup-heads are full to the brim with water.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you stare at the <kanji>full</kanji> flowers, you decide to write a <reading>man</reading>ga (<ja>まん</ja>) about them. Your head is full of manga ideas!
data.reading_hint: Soon you have full color pages, full of stories about both of these tsunami-filled flowers and their adventures together. And when you're done, your heart is full as well. Awwww.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>moon</radical> who stays in <radical>bed</radical> all day every day will soon become <kanji>obese</kanji>. A healthy moon needs movement and exercise to stay fit and not become obese. If a moon stays in bed all day, they’ll be sure to grow obese over time.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this moon in bed, slowly getting bigger and bigger, becoming more obese every day. Hear the sound of the bed creaking and cracking as the moon grows larger and larger.
data.reading_mnemonic: But once the moon gets <kanji>obese</kanji> enough, he turns into a super <reading>he</reading>ro (<ja>ひ</ja>)! He is, super obese moon! The most obese hero in all of history.
data.reading_hint: Imagine super obese moon the super hero. His powers are rolling and sitting on things. See super obese moon in his little cape and marvel at the fact that he’s even capable of movement.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>gladiator</radical> only sees himself (<radical>oneself</radical>) on those big <kanji>scroll</kanji>s they advertise the fights with. Gladiators don't get mirrors and there are no cameras or videos yet. The scroll drawings are all they get of themselves.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being a gladiator. Your big fight is coming and you're the  main event! Look at the scroll for the fight and try to find yourself.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you look at the <kanji>scroll</kanji> you realize... you look just like Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (<ja>かん</ja>)! You excitedly fist pump and start showing everyone how cool you are.
data.reading_hint:
After a while of showing off the scroll, someone finally pulls you aside and says, "That guy isn't you, it's the real Genghis Khan. He's coming to the event and he's against you. So. Nice knowing you."

Oh.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You want to get your <radical>fingers</radical> on the <radical>humble</radical> <radical>stool</radical>, so you dedicate your life to <kanji>search</kanji> for it. Wait, the humble stool? You know, like the holy grail or the arc of the covenant, but it's called the humble stool. It's from some bible or something, I promise.
data.meaning_hint: Now you have to search through a bunch of religious texts for this humble stool with your fingers. Don't go too fast and get paper cuts!
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>search</kanji> and you search and, unfortunately, you spend your entire life searching and you die without finding the humble stool. But don't worry, your <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>) comes back and now you get to continue your search but with afterlife powers!
data.reading_hint: You dedicated your soul to searching, and now that your soul is free from its body, you can continue the search until you find it!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>thread</radical> is <radical>mix</radical>ed all around and begins to <kanji>strangle</kanji> you.
data.meaning_hint: Just imagine thread everywhere, mixing in with everything. It's all around, and no matter where you go you get more and more caught in this thread. Eventually it tightens because you're trying to escape, and you feel yourself having trouble breathing. Imagine the moment when you realize you're getting strangled.
data.reading_mnemonic: As you are <kanji>strangle</kanji>d you see who set this trap. (What else could it be, with all this thread everywhere?) It is <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>, who just watches you as you lose consciousness, tapping his fingers together.
data.reading_hint: In your final moments before you are totally strangled, you think you see a little thread come out of his butt. "I should have done my WaniKani reviews" is your last thought.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>criminal</radical> that stole your <radical>car</radical> was your <kanji>comrade</kanji>! You thought the two of you were friends, but you were probably wrong.
data.meaning_hint: Just because someone is your comrade doesn't mean they actually like you. Don't let your guard down and let them near your car.
data.reading_mnemonic: You feel really weird about this whole situation so you write your <kanji>comrade</kanji> a <reading>hai</reading>ku (<ja>はい</ja>). It's really all you can do, since your car is long gone.
data.reading_hint:
Comrade, what the heck
I want to get my car back
I thought we were friends.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Behind a <radical>building</radical>, a <radical>cleat</radical>-wearing <radical>wolverine</radical> is holding his <radical>heart</radical> and trying to <kanji>hide</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You know the phrase, "You can run, but you can't hide?" This wolverine can't run anymore so he's trying to hide (even though he knows it probably won't work).
data.reading_mnemonic: The wolverine looks up at the building he's trying to <kanji>hide</kanji> behind and see it's an <reading>inn</reading> (<ja>いん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Lucky wolverine! Inns are good for hiding. The staff isn't supposed to give out his room number, and there are tons of different rooms for him to hide in.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Somebody got <radical>dirt</radical> on your <radical>fingers</radical> and <radical>dirt</radical> on your <radical>toe</radical>s so you're going to <kanji>hang</kanji> them upside-down and slap them with your dirty extremities.
data.meaning_hint: If someone got dirt all up in your finger and toe business wouldn't you want to hang them too?
data.reading_mnemonic: You have this person <kanji>hang</kanji>ing upside-down but they don't seem to be suffering enough, so you hit them with your <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). No mercy.
data.reading_hint: Don't get dirt on me, buddy. Or I'll hang you upside-down and hit you with my car. Then you'll be sorry.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>husband</radical> marries a <radical>husband</radical> while the <radical>sun</radical> goes down and the men <kanji>replace</kanji> their solitary lives with one of everlasting companionship. Instead of one husband and one wife, we have two husbands here. They shed their lives of bachelorhood and replace it with one of monogamy.
data.meaning_hint: See these two husbands as the sun sets under them. Listen to them each saying their vows, expressing how they could never replace one another.
data.reading_mnemonic: After the ceremony, the husband and his husband get in a <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>) and drive off into the sunset. They’ll never be able to <kanji>replace</kanji> this memory with anything. Truly it is the happiest day of these husbands’ lives.
data.reading_hint: See the husbands driving off into the sunset in their car. Hear the engine rumble as the car speeds off into the distance.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>flag</radical> is <radical>old</radical> but that doesn't mean it's not still <kanji>alive</kanji>. This is a living flag, and it gets old just like other living things.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine the old flag with a face and mouth and eyes and nose... it talks and listens and everything else. It's a flag that's <kanji>alive</kanji> D:
data.reading_mnemonic: The flag that is old and <kanji>alive</kanji> is actually a Buddhist relic (that's why it's alive, in fact ... and old!). But, it's a really dumb relic, so it's put in little <reading>kyo</reading>to (<ja>きょ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Not as cool as a real relic, it's put in this dumb Little Kyoto shrine that's basically just a tourist attraction. Eh, whatever.

data.meaning_mnemonic: "A <radical>scooter</radical>!" you <radical>announce</radical>. You are announcing this because you decided this is what you would <kanji>create</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being at a maker's contest. Each person has to announce loudly what they'll create, then they have to create it.
data.reading_mnemonic: But, a scooter has been <kanji>create</kanji>d before. What is different about yours? The scooter you will create is specifically designed to keep <reading>zo</reading>mbies (<ja>ぞう</ja>) busy.
data.reading_hint: Imagine the scooter you created with a zombie on it. It's a perfect place for the zombie to get stuck and scooted off into nowhere.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>fingers</radical> reaching towards you asking you to <radical>accept</radical> to <kanji>instruct</kanji> them. They're the fingers of students. And you're the teacher. See them reach out for knowledge. They want to accept this knowledge into their hearts and brains. Instruct them!
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself instructing a class full of knowledge hungry little kids. They reach out with their fingers to accept the truth you bring to them.
data.reading_mnemonic: "Yes! I will <kanji>instruct</kanji> you, my dear students!" you cry, "I will instruct you on how to open a small <reading>ju</reading>ice (<ja>じゅ</ja>) box!" That's right. These little kids need help learning how to open small juice boxes (small because kids are small).
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself instructing little kids how to punch the straw into small juice boxes. Hold it right-side-up! Don't squeeze too hard! Don't punch it through the other side! No! Don't bite the box! Instructing is hard!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take this <radical>comb</radical>, break the handle off, and use it to <radical>stamp</radical> your official <kanji>seal</kanji> of approval onto a document. It's kind of a messy <kanji>mark</kanji>ing process, but it gets the job done.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine breaking and bending a comb so you can use it to stamp your seal onto things.
data.reading_mnemonic: You need this <kanji>seal</kanji> to stay at an <reading>inn</reading> (<ja>いん</ja>). All inns require official paperwork, so you had to improvise and make a seal on the fly.
data.reading_hint: Hopefully the inn accepts this seal... or you aren't going to have a place to sleep tonight. And it kind of just looks like you dipped a comb in ink and pressed it around on some paper.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In your <radical>warehouse</radical> you use your <radical>knife</radical> to <kanji>create</kanji>. You keep old pieces of wood in your warehouse, and you use your knife to carve them into new things that only you could create.
data.meaning_hint: What do you create in your warehouse? Picture all the different things you could create in your mind.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you <kanji>create</kanji> it's good for your <reading>sou</reading>l (<ja>そう</ja>). It's so freeing, in fact, that when you get really into your creating, sometimes you'd swear your soul was floating a little bit outside of your body. But every time you notice, it sinks back down. Hmm.
data.reading_hint: When you create something your soul is happy! It's good for you, you know?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>loiter</radical> around a <radical>black hole</radical>, waiting for it to finish destroying and switch to <kanji>restore</kanji> mode. You were told all black holes finish eventually, and when they do you can press a button to restore everything back to the way it was.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine loitering around near (but not too near!) the black hole waiting for it finish so you can restore the galaxy.
data.reading_mnemonic: Finally there's nothing else for the black hole to eat so you hit the <kanji>restore</kanji> button.... but nothing happens. "Oh <reading>f**k</reading> (<ja>ふく</ja>) you!" you scream as you realize you were lied to.
data.reading_hint: Maybe if you yell f**k you enough things will be restored. Ha. No. Everything's gone and it's your fault for being gullible.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>loiter</radical> around your <radical>master</radical> until he <kanji>depart</kanji>s. You have a lot more freedom to do things after your master has departed, so until that time you just loiter about looking busy and staying out of his way.
data.meaning_hint: Picture yourself loitering around your master’s fancy mansion. You’re pretending to dust things off, but you’re actually just waiting for him to depart.
data.reading_mnemonic: Finally, it's time for your master to <kanji>depart</kanji> and he calls to you and says, "You are the <ja><reading>王</reading></ja> (<ja>おう</ja>) of the house now. Take care of everything while I'm gone."
data.reading_hint: Your master has departed! You are the <ja>王</ja> now!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your new <radical>car</radical> doesn’t <radical>mix</radical> well with the other cars in your garage because its color is in stark <kanji>contrast</kanji> to the others. All of your other cars are pristine white in color, but this new car is a mix of lots of colors. It almost looks like a peacock or something it’s so colorful. Such a contrast.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this garage of yours with a sea of white cars. Now there is a new car that really sticks out like a sore thumb. Imagine yourself looking out over your cars and seeing this wacky car practically jumping out at you.
data.reading_mnemonic: What did I say this car looks like? Oh that’s right, a pea<reading>cock</reading> (<ja>かく</ja>). This car looks like a peacock. It’s the color of a peacock and you’ll look like you’re peacocking when you’re out on the town driving it. It really is such a stark <kanji>contrast</kanji> to like, every other car out there.
data.reading_hint: See yourself driving around in this peacock car. Hear the engine purr as strangers jeer and yell at you. This car sure does get a lot of attention, doesn’t it?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Out of <radical>bamboo</radical>, you make a <radical>brush</radical> – a <kanji>writing brush</kanji>. This is no ordinary brush, mind you. It is a brush specifically designed for writing elegant characters. And it’s made from bamboo!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself using this bamboo writing brush. Do you know many kanji? Of course you do! Imagine yourself writing them all with this nice writing brush. It’s actually fun to write things with it!
data.reading_mnemonic: Once the <kanji>writing brush</kanji> <reading>hits</reading> (<ja>ひつ</ja>) that paper, it’s like you transform into a totally different person. All of a sudden you’re a master calligrapher, writing anything and everything in a most beautiful fashion. Once that brush hits the paper, it’s on!
data.reading_hint: Imagine the sound the brush makes when it hits the paper. It’s a bit of a plop, and then kind of a scratching sound as the brush bristles move around. Really focus on this sound that the brush makes when it hits the paper.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You hold <radical>gold</radical> <radical>fins</radical> in your <radical>mouth</radical> while shopping for pencil <kanji>lead</kanji> at the store. This pencil lead store only accepts gold fins as payment, but your fins don’t fit in your pockets and you need your hands to carry the lead so the gold fins go in your mouth.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having these gold fins in your mouth. Taste the metal as your tongue runs over them.
data.reading_mnemonic: You pay for your <kanji>lead</kanji> but the cashier puts it in your mouth where the gold fins were and... everything <reading>en</reading>ds (<ja>えん</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Lead poisoning, huh? What a way for everything to end...

data.meaning_mnemonic: You keep all of your <radical>shellfish</radical> under a <radical>roof</radical> down the <radical>street</radical> and it's your <kanji>savings</kanji>. Shellfish used to be used as money way back, and these aren't shellfish you're spending, they're ones you're saving up for later.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine walking down the street to deposit more shellfish into your special savings and gaze happily at the huge pile you keep far enough away that you aren't tempted to spend it.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you want to withdraw from your <kanji>savings</kanji> you force yourself to use <reading>cho</reading>psticks (<ja>ちょ</ja>) to pick up the shellfish. They're especially slippery, hard to use chopsticks too, that way it's really hard to take too much out of your savings.
data.reading_hint: Imagine trying to lift up a shellfish with a pair of smooth chopsticks. It slips right out. Ugh! I guess that's good though, because it's a savings for a reason (you shouldn't be spending it)!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>old</radical> <radical>winter</radical> is to blame for today's <kanji>circumstance</kanji>. It is the <kanji>reason</kanji> things are bad now.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine a poor, broken town. And, imagine the mayor of a town telling their people that things are bad because of that bad old winter. "It's to blame for our circumstance!" he yells.
data.reading_mnemonic: In reality, this <kanji>circumstance</kanji> was actually caused by a single <ja><reading>子</reading></ja> (<ja>こ</ja>), though. This kid went through town, destroying everything in their path.
data.reading_hint: Imagine your kid character walking through town, using their super powers to destroy buildings and rot food.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There's a <radical>building</radical> standing in the way of the next <radical>chapter</radical> in your life, and it's <kanji>hinder</kanji>ing you. It's not like you couldn't find another way around, but it's definitely inconvenient.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this huge, tall building standing directly in the way. You peer around the other side and there is a book floating in the air that says "Chapter 5: Success and Happiness." Dang, you really want to get over there to that part of your life.
data.reading_mnemonic: Someone put this building here specifically to <kanji>hinder</kanji> you. They knew you were close to the next chapter of your life, and they wanted to hinder you really good. And there they are, sitting on a throne smirking. It's the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: The Shougun wants to hinder you and your life. He wants you to have to work harder so you become better, faster, and stronger than anyone else. Hindering you is his way of making sure you don't take the easy way out in life.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you see someone <radical>loiter</radical>ing around with <radical>horns</radical> on their head you'd be <radical>correct</radical> to <kanji>obey</kanji> and <kanji>accompany</kanji> them.
data.meaning_hint: First of all, this could be really fun. Second of all, if this person is a demon or something, you should really just obey them or they could curse you. What's the worst that could happen?!
data.reading_mnemonic: If you <kanji>obey</kanji> the horned man you'll end up with a ton of <reading>jew</reading>els (<ja>じゅう</ja>)!
data.reading_hint: You stole those jewels together and now you're an accomplice for accompanying him! You better hide those jewels!!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>ego</radical>... it's totally out of control. <kanji>I</kanji> mean, my ego isn't out of control. I'm the greatest. That's <kanji>me</kanji>. But your ego? Ugh, so out of control unlike my amazing ego.
data.meaning_hint: Just keep going with this sentence about the ego. You can't stop, because really it's your ego that's out of control. That's <kanji>I</kanji> when you're saying it.
data.reading_mnemonic: <kanji>I</kanji> am the greatest in the world! I am no baby like you, that's why. A baby who says "<reading>ga</reading> (<ja>が</ja>) ga ga ga!"
data.reading_hint: You're just destroying the ego of that other guy. "Why?" you ask? "Because <kanji>I</kanji> am the boss here. And you are the baby. Ego things."

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> that is <radical>white</radical>, traveling in the <radical>direction</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> is a <kanji>fierce</kanji> and <kanji>violent</kanji> force of nature. This white tsunami is chasing after winter, and that’s why the tsunami is white—it’s a winter tsunami. It’s the most fierce and most violent kind of tsunami in existence.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this white tsunami, more violent and fierce than any other tsunami you’ve ever seen, coming toward you. It’s very frightening. Feel the cold wetness it brings to your skin.
data.reading_mnemonic: The tsunami is too <kanji>fierce</kanji>, too <kanji>violent</kanji>, and before you realize what's happening, <reading>Gecki</reading> (<ja>げき</ja>), your beloved gecko, is lifted up and carried off into the air.
data.reading_hint: "Geecckkkiiiiii!!!" you scream in horror, as he's thrown about by the fierce, winter tsunami. You have to close your eyes. You can't watch Gecki go.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>head</radical> pinned to a <radical>tree</radical> by a <radical>knife</radical>. This person has been <kanji>stab</kanji>bed! They were stabbed so hard that they were pinned to the tree here.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine how much force you would need to stab someone to have the knife and go all the way through them and pin their head to a tree. That's a lot of force.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to know who did the <kanji>stab</kanji>bing, so you look around to see if the stabber is still in the area. But all you see is a <reading>shee</reading>p (<ja>し</ja>). Sheep can't stab people, right? They have hooves and probably can't pick up knives... right?
data.reading_hint: Imagine getting closer to the sheep and seeing blood on its wool. You squint your eyes and see some knives strapped to its back. Even closer and you see a little sign around it's neck that says, "Hello, I'm the Stabbing Sheep." Uh oh.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The "<radical>Cliff</radical> of <radical>Ten Thousand</radical> <radical>Power</radical>" is where you go if you want to be <kanji>encourage</kanji>d.
data.meaning_hint: If you can get to the top of the cliff, it will use its "ten thousand power" to encourage you.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you get there, it does <kanji>encourage</kanji> you. The cliff says "Hey, I encourage you to buy a <reading>ray</reading> (<ja>れい</ja>) gun."
data.reading_hint: A cliff is encouraging you to buy a ray gun for some reason. This is not the encouragement you expected, but it is encouragement nonetheless. You go back down the cliff and immediately buy a ray gun.

data.meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> using a <radical>measurement</radical> device (like a ruler) is a good way to <kanji>chastise</kanji> someone. They do something bad? Chastise them by slapping their wrists, their feet, their eyes, ears, anything! They say something out of turn? CHASTISE THEM!
data.meaning_hint: Imagine being chastised with a measurement device. Think how horrible it would be getting hit on your knuckles, your nose, or the back of your head. It would be awful. Imagine this experience.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're being <kanji>chastise</kanji>d because you tried to say something in English in <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. Everyone around you slowly turned around, eyes aflame and rulers in hand, ready to chastise you for uttering those forbidden words.
data.reading_hint: How could you say something in English while you're in <ja>とうきょう</ja>?! After you went to all the trouble to learn all this kanji and Japanese? Geez, we almost think you deserve to be chastised...

data.meaning_mnemonic: A broken <radical>car</radical> sits in a <radical>building</radical>. You need to get rid of it, so you <kanji>mail</kanji> it.
data.meaning_hint: You just put some postage on it and watch the mail carrier take it away like any other piece of mail.
data.reading_mnemonic: Who did you address this broken car <kanji>mail</kanji> to? You sent it to the <reading>you</reading>ths (<ja>ゆう</ja>) of the world.
data.reading_hint: You figure youths don't have cars anymore, so they could use one. Ugh, youths these days and their ride share apps.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>gold</radical> <radical>cross</radical>, you see a <kanji>needle</kanji> sticking out of it. The needle is right in the middle of the gold cross. If Jesus were on there, the needle would be sticking him right in the chest.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this golden cross in your head. Why do you suppose there’s this needle stuck in it? You try to pull it out but you can’t. Envision yourself straining, trying to get the thing out.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're about to give up on the <kanji>needle</kanji> when it pops out and flies directly into your <reading>shin</reading> (<ja>しん</ja>). Ouch! Now you're desperately trying to pull the needle out of your shin, but it really won't budge this time. Maybe you should have minded your own business.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a needle sticking into your shin. It hurts a ton. How would you try to get it out?

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>loiter</radical>ing <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>king</radical> in the <radical>winter</radical> is an <kanji>indication</kanji> or <kanji>sign</kanji> of something to come.
data.meaning_hint: We don't want to focus too much on what the indication / sign actually is, though, because it will take away from the <kanji>indication</kanji> part (which we want to remember). So, focus on the fact that this is some kind of indication that's important, but you don't know what that indication means or is... because we'll use that with the reading.
data.reading_mnemonic: When you spot a loitering mountain king in the winter, you know it's an <kanji>indication</kanji> that soon Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (<ja>ちょう</ja>) will appear. It's like a Groundhog's Day kind of situation, but instead it means Mrs. Chou is about to come out, perhaps early for the season.
data.reading_hint: Imagine an announcer watching the loitering mountain king, "There he is... and it's still winter. We all know what that means. It's a sign that Mrs. Chou will be coming out of hibernation soon." Then, you can imagine her bursting forth from the mountain, running down her street.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>soul</radical> floating around a <radical>tombstone</radical> acting <kanji>suspicious</kanji>. To be fair, if a soul is going to be anywhere, a tombstone is probably high up on the list, but this one seems like it's doing something weird.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine inching closer to this suspicious soul floating around a tombstone. What do you think it's doing?
data.reading_mnemonic:
You sneak around the tombstone to see what this <kanji>suspicious</kanji> soul is doing, and you realize it's pretending to <reading>ka</reading>yak (<ja>かい</ja>). The soul is sitting behind the tombstone, in a small kayak, moving its arms like it's rowing through water.

Even more suspicious, the soul seems to be wearing a <reading>ke</reading>vlar (<ja>け</ja>) vest. Considering the soul is already dead, this doesn't seem like something it will need.
data.reading_hint: Picture a suspicious, kevlar wearing, kayaking soul. The afterlife may be more interesting than you thought.

data.meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>grass</radical> near a <radical>rice paddy</radical> sits a <radical>creeper</radical> that is some sort of a <radical>dog</radical> <kanji>beast</kanji>, a vicious <kanji>animal</kanji>. This creeper isn’t just a normal dog, it is more beast-like, more like a feral animal than domesticated pet.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this beast creeping, low to the ground, in the grass around the rice paddy. It's got its eyes on you. Uh oh.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>beast</kanji> is guarding its precious <reading>jew</reading>els (<ja>じゅう</ja>), which it buried in the grass or the rice paddy somewhere. If you don't want the beast to think you're coming to steal those jewels, you better keep your distance.
data.reading_hint: All beasts have something they're trying to protect. In this case, it's some beastly jewels.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>hole</radical>, you see a <radical>big</radical> guy who looks like he wants to <kanji>stab</kanji> you. You don’t want him to stab you, so you make sure not to fall into the big hole that houses the big guy that wants to stab you big time.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this hole – it’s like, super big. The guy is really big. They’re terrifying enough on their own, but put them together and you’ve got a big problem. You feel very afraid of this hole and getting stabbed. Just don’t fall in, okay?
data.reading_mnemonic: You fall in the big hole. What did I just tell you not to do!? He’s <reading>totes</reading> (<ja>とつ</ja>) going to <kanji>stab</kanji> you for sure. Totes.
data.reading_hint: This big guy inside the big hole is totes going to stab you. Why did you fall in?? Feel the big guy press you up against the wall of the hole as he begins to stab you repeatedly.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You take some <radical>flowers</radical> and some <radical>fruit</radical> and you make a <kanji>cake</kanji> out of it. It’s a very nice looking, flavorful cake. The fruit makes it taste great and the flowers make for great cake decorations.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this cake you have made. It’s majestic. Now taste some of it. It is one great tasting cake. Imagine yourself eating the best cake in all of ever.
data.reading_mnemonic: You’re standing back, admiring your <kanji>cake</kanji> when you hear a <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>) engine revving and before you know it your cake has been run over. The car came out of nowhere and ran your cake right over, spraying fruit cake bits and flowers all over the place. Stupid car!
data.reading_hint: Hear the roar of the car engine as you get splattered in the face with the cake. Wipe it off of your face just in time to see the car speeding off into the distance. Also, recall that this kanji shares a reading with the similar kanji, <ja>果</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: During a <radical>tsunami</radical>, your <radical>lip ring</radical> is ripped off while you’re trying to cross a <kanji>river</kanji>. There was no other path to safety, you had to cross the raging river, but you lost your footing and smashed your face on a rock and lost your lip ring.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine how painful this would be, having your lip ring ripped from your lip. It would hurt a lot. Touch your lip and imagine missing half of it. Yikes.
data.reading_mnemonic: But why were you trying to cross this <kanji>river</kanji> anyway? Well your <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>) was on the other side of it, and you figured if you could get to your car you could outrun the tsunami and be safe. Too bad you fell and ripped out your lip ring though.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself fording the river, all wet and cold from the water. Keeping your eyes on your car, you move slowly across. Look at the car. Look at it!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You're trying to use your <radical>fingers</radical> to cause a <radical>landslide</radical> so you have to <kanji>shake</kanji> the earth. You probably won't succeed, but the best you can do is to shake your hands on the dirt as hard as you can. It looks like you're trying to <kanji>wave</kanji> at the ground now.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine shaking your fingers at the dirt. Do you think you can shake the dirt hard enough to cause a landslide (spoilers, no).
data.reading_mnemonic: You think you finally got the earth to <kanji>shake</kanji> but when you look down it's just your <reading>shin</reading>s (<ja>しん</ja>). Darn you shins, I thought I made some progress. Hey wait... why won't you stop?!
data.reading_hint: Imagine your shins shaking, your hands are waving, and they won't stop. No! You shouldn't have tried to start a landslide. This was a bad idea!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> going down your <radical>dry</radical> face is just <kanji>sweat</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Sweat really does feel like a tsunami though. Wow, it's dry and hot out right now!
data.reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sweat</kanji> isn't just on your face, it's also dripping down your <reading>ass</reading> (<ja>あせ</ja>).
data.reading_hint: The one place you wish sweat wouldn't go, but somehow it always does: the ass.

data.meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>moon</radical>, it’s easy to turn a <radical>pig</radical> into <kanji>pork</kanji>. The low gravity of the moon makes the whole process much easier and cost efficient. Soon, all the pig farming will be done on the moon and there will never be a pork shortage ever again.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine going to a pig farm/restaurant on the moon. You’re in a space suit, eating some space pork. It’s delicious. Imagine the best pork you’ve ever had. This is better than that.
data.reading_mnemonic: At this particular pig restaurant, they have a secret ingredient that goes onto their <kanji>pork</kanji>. Lots and lots of <reading>butte</reading>r (<ja>ぶた</ja>). Okay, so it’s not that big of a secret. But boy is it delicious. Mmm, butter.
data.reading_hint: Butter and pork. A match made in heaven! Imagine yourself scarfing down this buttered pork by the pound. You’re stuffed, but you have to eat more. It’s soooo gooood.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leaf</radical> has to do the same <radical>task</radical> <kanji>again</kanji> and again. Grow out of a tree, change color, fall to the ground, get absorbed back into the tree, then start all over again.
data.meaning_hint: Picture all of the tasks a leaf has to do in its lifetime again and again.
data.reading_mnemonic: Once <kanji>again</kanji> the leaf picks up a <reading>saw</reading> (<ja>さ</ja>) and cuts itself off of the tree at the end of fall, like some kind of invincible <reading>cy</reading>borg (<ja>さい</ja>).
data.reading_hint: Picture a leaf sawing itself off of a tree. Then picture it again. Now picture Bill Nye pointing to it and saying, "This leaf is a cyborg. See how it has little robot parts, allowing it to do this again and again?"

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stand</radical> with another <radical>woman</radical> and, with your <radical>fingers</radical>, <kanji>adjoin</kanji> yourselves together. You are united, you are one.
data.meaning_hint: Look around you. Other women are adjoining their fingers and standing with you. There's hundreds, no, thousands of you standing together.
data.reading_mnemonic: All of the women who are now <kanji>adjoin</kanji>ing together are in <reading>sets</reading> (<ja>せつ</ja>). Sets of two, of course. One woman with another woman, standing in unison.
data.reading_hint: Picture a bunch of women protesting together. They're holding hands in sets, adjoined together.

data.meaning_mnemonic: There once was an <radical>animal</radical> with an <radical>insect</radical> friend who felt very <kanji>alone</kanji> unless he was around. An animal and an insect are an unlikely pairing, but these two get along delightfully and hate to be alone without the other.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this animal and this insect. Let’s say it’s a flea and a dog. Imagine them going everywhere together. To the park, getting ice cream, even the drive in movie theater. They’re inseparable.
data.reading_mnemonic: One activity that the animal can never do <kanji>alone</kanji> is solve Su<reading>doku</reading> (<ja>どく</ja>) puzzles. The insect always has to help him out with them, and together they are an unstoppable Sudoku solving team.
data.reading_hint: Picture this animal with the insect on his head doing a Sudoku. See the insect hopping around on the animals head shouting answers and suggestions into the animal’s ear. How cute.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>fortune</radical> radical and the <kanji>fortune</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! But it also means <kanji>occupy</kanji> as well, so don’t forget that. Fortune and occupy both occupy the same radical.
data.meaning_hint: Just remember that this kanji also means occupy and you’ll be just fine.
data.reading_mnemonic: To <kanji>occupy</kanji> some free time you have, you go and get your <kanji>fortune</kanji> told at a fortune teller. Your fortune is that you’ll have an encounter with a <reading>cen</reading>taur (<ja>せん</ja>) in the near future. Just then you realize that the fortune teller is actually a centaur! The fortune has come true!
data.reading_hint: Imagine getting your fortune told by a centaur fortune teller. Do you trust this mythical beast to know your future? Watch him manipulate his crystal ball as his hooves stomp the ground beneath him.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Someone is reaching out with their <radical>fingers</radical> to <radical>call</radical> for you. They <kanji>beckon</kanji> you closer, this way.
data.meaning_hint: Something about the way they're beckoning you with their fingers is really enticing. You can't help but walk toward them.
data.reading_mnemonic: The person <kanji>beckon</kanji>ing you is the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>). You can't help but obey the Shougun's beckoning call.
data.reading_hint: Even if the Shougun didn't have an army that would crush you if you didn't come when he called, you'd go anyway. Those beckoning fingers are just so... weirdly enticing.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Cut this <radical>comb</radical> up with your <radical>weapon</radical> and turn it into the <kanji>steps</kanji> for some <kanji>stairs</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: When you think about it, a comb is like a ladder. So if you cut all the rungs off with your weapon and put them on the ground, they turn into stairs!
data.reading_mnemonic: You slowly work to create these <kanji>stairs</kanji>, you have to slice up a lot of combs, and at <reading>dawn</reading> (<ja>だん</ja>) they are done!
data.reading_hint: Imagine standing at the top of the stairs you made yourself, looking down at the entire town below you, as the light of dawn breaks and fills everything before you with light. And now more people can see this beautiful sight if they climb your steps.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you eat a <radical>rice paddy</radical> the size of the <radical>moon</radical>, your <kanji>stomach</kanji> is going to hurt. All the rice in a rice paddy the size of the moon is way too much rice for anyone to consume. If you do, your stomach is going to ache like crazy.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine having a whole rice paddy in your stomach. A rice paddy the size of the moon. Your stomach hurts a lot. You feel like you’re going to throw up.
data.reading_mnemonic: From the sky, an eagle swoops down and flies right into your distended <kanji>stomach</kanji>. Bam! The <reading>ea</reading>gle (<ja>い</ja>) hits your stomach and you vomit up the entire moon sized rice paddy.
data.reading_hint: This eagle saw your stomach distress and decided to help by making you barf. Hear the screech of the eagle as it swoops down and rams you in the stomach.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Inside this <radical>moon</radical> is a <radical>black hole</radical>... haha just kidding, it's your <kanji>belly</kanji>! It's beautiful and round like the moon and it eats up everything you give it like a black hole. What a good <kanji>stomach</kanji> you have!
data.meaning_hint: Look down at your perfect belly. It's looking back up at you.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you don't treat your <kanji>belly</kanji> with respect, when you look down at it, it'll yell, "<reading>F**k</reading> (<ja>ふく</ja>) you!" Be nice to your stomach!
data.reading_hint: Forget to eat lunch? Belly grumbles f**k you. Tell someone you're fat and need to lose weight? Belly cries f**k you. Be nice to your belly.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>sick</radical> <radical>mama</radical> tries to do a <radical>task</radical> she's filled with <kanji>pain</kanji>!
data.meaning_hint: Sick people shouldn't have to do things, of course they're in pain. You shouldn't let your mama do anything if she's in pain, do it for her!
data.reading_mnemonic: Your mama's <kanji>pain</kanji> is <reading>too</reading> (<ja>つう</ja>) much for her to handle, so now you have to do all of her tasks too.
data.reading_hint: You finish doing your tasks and hers too, and you ask her, "How is the pain now, Mama?" "THE PAIN IS TOO MUCH!" she cries. Oh mama.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you're on your <radical>scooter</radical> and you run over a <radical>root</radical>, you'll need to <kanji>retreat</kanji>. The roots have obviously <kanji>reject</kanji>ed you, they want you to leave, so you should.
data.meaning_hint: Picture the roots raising up a little bit from the ground and tripping up your scooter. They reject you, so you should just retreat.
data.reading_mnemonic: You're trying to <kanji>retreat</kanji> by scooting backwards, but the roots grab onto your <reading>tie</reading> (<ja>たい</ja>). You try to pull your tie off but it's just getting tighter and tighter around your neck.
data.reading_hint: You didn't retreat fast enough, the roots are rejecting your life, and strangling you with your own tie.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>flag</radical> by the <radical>exit</radical> letting you know to <kanji>yield</kanji>. There’s cross traffic just outside the exit, and the flag lets you know that you need to yield to them.
data.meaning_hint: Look at this flag telling you to yield. Now look through the exit right by the flag. You can see a bunch of people out there walking. Imagine standing by the exit, yielding to the other people until you have an opening. Hear the hustle and bustle of the people as you wait.
data.reading_mnemonic: Even though the flag told you to <kanji>yield</kanji>, you’re starting to lose your patience. The people walking outside the exit are all a bunch of crazy old <reading>coots</reading> (<ja>くつ</ja>)! These crazy coots keep walking right in front of the door, getting in the way. The old coots aren’t even going anywhere, they just keep looping around to obstruct the way!
data.reading_hint: Darn coots! Forget the yield flag, it’s time to exit. Imagine busting out of the exit, punching and pushing your way through the old coots. Hear them scream and shout “Augh! My hip!” as you plow through them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If your <radical>soul</radical> is lying in the <radical>grass</radical> in a <radical>treasure chest</radical>, you're going to <kanji>worry</kanji> about it. It's just sitting there, out in the open, waiting for anyone to come and open it.
data.meaning_hint: Picture your soul curled up inside this treasure chest that's just sitting out on the grass. Anyone could open it up and look inside, and this worries you quite a bit!
data.reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, you also <kanji>worry</kanji> about opening it yourself. You stand in front of the chest and think, "Should I open it? <reading>Nah, yah</reading> (<ja>なや</ja>). Wait. Nah. Yah. Dang, you can't make up your mind.
data.reading_hint: You worry about what you'll find if you look directly at your soul. But you also worry about what will happen if someone else looks. So you're stuck in a constant state of worrying: nah or yah?!

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>sun</radical> while holding a <radical>comb</radical> in a <radical>cage</radical> and sitting on a <radical>stool</radical>, you comb your hair in your <kanji>spare time</kanji>. Since you’re in a cage, you actually fashioned this comb yourself, so it’s a little messed up, missing a prong. You’re working on improving it in your spare time, and you also use it to style your mop.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself in your spare time, sitting on this stool in a cage in the sun. Feel the warmth of the sun on your body and feel the metal bars of the cage holding you in. You try to forget about your situation by combing your hair with the comb. The comb radical is a little modified, so be sure to remember that you made this comb yourself and it’s a little wonky.
data.reading_mnemonic: So how did you get in this cage? Well, before you used to comb your hair in your <kanji>spare time</kanji>, you used to steal <reading>ca</reading>rs (<ja>か</ja>). You’d stolen many a car in your day, but you finally got caught in the act of stealing a car, and now you’re spending all of your spare time in that cage, just combing your hair.
data.reading_hint: Picture yourself in this cage. You’re going to be there for life because you’d stolen too many cars. Feel the tears run down your face as you continue to comb your hair. You’re going to die in this cage.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Taking a <radical>thread</radical> and moving to the <radical>sound</radical> of the music, a <radical>drunkard</radical> makes a <kanji>weave</kanji> through some fabric. He’s using the thread to weave his clothes back together after he damaged them in a fall down the stairs. You know, because he’s a drunkard.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this drunkard bipping and bopping to the sound of the music as he weaves this thread through his clothes to repair them.
data.reading_mnemonic: This drunkard is actually a <reading>Sheikh</reading> (<ja>しき</ja>) (an Arabic leader), but he’s just fallen on hard times and has been hitting the bottle pretty hard lately. The piece of clothing he is using the thread to <kanji>weave</kanji> back together is one of his fancy formal robes.
data.reading_hint: Imagine this drunken Sheikh again, only this time he is moving to the sound of some Arabic music. You know what that sounds like, right?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>substitute</radical> some <radical>shellfish</radical> for collateral so your friend will <kanji>lend</kanji> you some money. Normally he would ask for something more valuable, but you’ve convinced him to substitute these shellfish for what he would normally take as collateral when lending to people.
data.meaning_hint: "Shellfish used to be money! People used to lend them to each other all the time!" you say to your friend. "Hmm... okay, I guess so," they say skeptically.
data.reading_mnemonic: You want your friend to <kanji>lend</kanji> you some money so you can buy yourself a <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>). You need money and a car a lot more than you need this pile of shellfish, so you’re happy to put them up as collateral for the loan.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself in this new car that you got with the money your friend lent you. Hear the roar of the engine and feel the wind in your hair.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you're riding your <radical>scooter</radical> through some <radical>rice</radical>, it's likely you've gone <kanji>astray</kanji>. Also you might be <kanji>lost</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Usually there aren't paved areas inside areas of rice. You must be really lost if you ended up here with your scooter.
data.reading_mnemonic: You got so <kanji>lost</kanji> and went so <kanji>astray</kanji> you ended up on the <reading>May</reading>flower <reading>めい</reading>, a ship that eventually took you across the Atlantic Ocean. Now you've really, really gone astray.
data.reading_hint: How you got so lost that you ended up on an old ship from 1620 is beyond my understanding. But you did it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drunkard</radical> who has his <radical>mouth</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical>, has a <radical>heart</radical> that is <kanji>misguided</kanji>. First of all, he tries to drink his problems away, but worse, he's so drunk he's trying to drink out of the ground.
data.meaning_hint: Picture this misguided drunkard. His whole deal is messed up.
data.reading_mnemonic: Nowadays we don't say <kanji>misguided</kanji>, we say <reading>wack</reading> (<ja>わく</ja>). Like, damn that drunkard is so messed up, he's wack.
data.reading_hint: Did I do it? Did I figure out the kid lingo? Am I cool? Or am I just another wack, misguided adult?

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> to some <radical>grain</radical> and some <radical>stairs</radical>: I want to <kanji>invite</kanji> you to my place.
data.meaning_hint: So you do. You invite a stalk of grain and a set of stairs to your home.
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>invite</kanji>d them to your home because your roommate was having a party and inviting a lot of <reading>you</reading>ths (<ja>ゆう</ja>) over. You wanted to look cool, so you invited some grain and some stairs, the two coolest things you could think of.
data.reading_hint: Surprisingly, the youths were impressed and spent a long time trying to talk to them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>capital</radical>, a broken <radical>dog</radical> begins to <kanji>settle in</kanji>. This dog used to live in the country, but he kept getting caught in bear and fox traps which busted the poor dog up. The dog didn’t want to live like this, so he decided to settle in the capital city where there aren’t pesky animal traps to get caught in.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this dog going to the capital and settling in. The poor dog looks pretty messed up though. The radical for dog in this kanji is a bit modified, so just remember that the dog in this story is all messed up.
data.reading_mnemonic: In order to help the dog <kanji>settle in</kanji>, the capital cobbler makes him a pair of <reading>shoe</reading>s (<ja>しゅう</ja>). The shoes help walk on his hurt legs, but more importantly, they help him relax and feel like a dog again.
data.reading_hint: Watch the broken dog settle in to his new shoes in his new home in the capital. The old dog can finally enjoy life!

data.meaning_mnemonic: Someone just asked you to <radical>say</radical> which <radical>direction</radical> they should <kanji>visit</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You better think long and hard about where you think they should visit before you say so. They're relying on you.
data.reading_mnemonic: You end up saying, "You should <kanji>visit</kanji> my <reading>ho</reading>me (<ja>ほう</ja>)." How kind of you!
data.reading_hint: Your home is just over that direction, and it's your favorite place to visit, so why wouldn't this stranger want to visit your home too?! So come and visit my home, random person!

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> with a broken <radical>heart</radical> is very <kanji>angry</kanji>. She had her heart broken by some jerk and now she’s sitting on the stool, just stewing over the guy and how angry she is with him.
data.meaning_hint: This woman is so angry! Pretend you are the woman. Sit on your stool and feel your heart, painful in your chest, as you fume and think about how angry you are.
data.reading_mnemonic: The guy who broke your heart and made you so <kanji>angry</kanji> was such a <reading>do</reading>g (<ja>ど</ja>). He cheated on you multiple times, with your mother and your sister! What a dog!
data.reading_hint: You’re so angry! Imagine your ex as being an actual dog and picture yourself hitting it right in the face with your stool. Hear the dog whimpering in pain as you demolish it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You want to go to the <radical>sun</radical> so you set up a <radical>slide</radical> <radical>twenty</radical> stories tall so you can <kanji>ascend</kanji> into the heavens.
data.meaning_hint: Feel the air whoosh past your face as you shoot off the end of the long slide and ascend into the air. It's starting to get hot and the sun is getting closer!
data.reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>ascend</kanji> into the sky and toward the sun because the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) said so. He's testing out some space travel technology (the twenty story slide) and you're his guinea pig.
data.reading_hint: As you ascend, look back through tear-filled eyes and see the Shougun staring up at you. He nods slightly. You've pleased him.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Closing each <radical>eye</radical> is something that the <radical>peoples</radical> do before they <kanji>sleep</kanji>. The peoples can’t sleep with both eyes open and they can’t sleep with just one eye open either. Peoples have to close each eye before they can sleep.
data.meaning_hint: You are one of these peoples, so imagine yourself closing your eyes and sleeping. Go ahead and do it right now. Close one eye, and then the other. Now imagine yourself sleeping.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reason you want to <kanji>sleep</kanji> is because all the other peoples were <reading>mean</reading> (<ja>みん</ja>) to you. They were so mean that the only way you could get over it was to close your eyes and sleep. You just want to sleep.
data.reading_hint: Those other peoples were really mean to you. Imagine all the mean things they were saying to you. What did they say? Think about all these mean things as you close your eyes and drift off to sleep. Also keep in mind that this kanji has the same reading as <ja>民</ja>, which is included in this kanji.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>eye</radical>s start to close as you drive your <radical>car</radical> because you’re getting <kanji>drowsy</kanji>. This is a very dangerous way to drive your car, especially since your car is missing its top and its bottom. This is no time to be getting drowsy. Keep your eyes open and drive for your life!
data.meaning_hint: Feel yourself getting drowsy as you drive this goofy car. You’re so tired. Struggle to keep your eyes open. Also visualize this car missing its top and its bottom because the car radical is modified.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reason you’re so <kanji>drowsy</kanji>, and also the reason your car is missing part of its bottom, is because you took one of the car’s tires and made a tire <reading>swi</reading>ng (<ja>すい</ja>) out of it. You’d been swinging on the tire swing all day and now you’re super drowsy and worn out.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself swinging on this tire swing. You’ve been swinging for a while and you’re getting really drowsy.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When someone is <radical>sick</radical> in order to diagnose the <radical>correct</radical> cause and treatment, you need to check their <kanji>symptom</kanji>s. You have to be especially careful too, because if you get a symptom wrong, you could kill them!
data.meaning_hint: If you know all of the symptoms for each and every sickness you'd be able to cure them all!
data.reading_mnemonic: You need to figure out the <kanji>symptom</kanji>s the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (<ja>しょう</ja>) is having. This is really serious too, so you better be correct about which sickness he has. If something bad happens to the Shougun it will be off with your head.
data.reading_hint: You get all up close and personal with the Shougun. Hmm, his symptoms are watery eyes, stuffy nose, angry shouting (wait no, that's not a symptom, is it?). Don't mess up!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have a special <radical>thread</radical> in your <radical>towel</radical> you can use to make it <radical>stand</radical> up by <kanji>tighten</kanji>ing it.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine pulling this thread and watch as your towel tightens and goes rigid, standing up almost completely on its own (except that the thread did it).
data.reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>tighten</kanji> your towel before you eat <reading>ta</reading>ter (<ja>てい</ja>) tots every night. That way it stands up nice and straight next to your eating chair, ready for all that delicious tater tot grease that gets on your fingers.
data.reading_hint: A tightened towel stands up for easy grease cleanup. No wiping on your pants, no dripping on the floor.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>scooter</radical> is <radical>white</radical>. This color will <kanji>urge</kanji> and <kanji>compel</kanji> you to use it. Scooter companies use colors to get you to do what they want. Some would say they are trying to <kanji>coerce</kanji> you, even.
data.meaning_hint: Look at how white the scooter is. It urges you to use it. It compels you. You feel coerced...
data.reading_mnemonic: When they <kanji>urge</kanji>, <kanji>compel</kanji> and <kanji>coerce</kanji> you like this, they are <reading>hack</reading>ing (<ja>はく</ja>) your brain.
data.reading_hint:
Really all marketing, advertising, and the like is just a hack of your brain.

Hint: If you see <ja>白</ja> in a kanji, there's a good likelihood the reading will be <ja>はく</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>leather</radical> and <radical>change</radical> it into <kanji>shoes</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: You start with a sheet of leather. Now imagine yourself going through the process of changing them to shoes. Smell the leather and feel it, too.
data.reading_mnemonic: Some <kanji>shoes</kanji> aren’t made from leather anymore these days, but you know who always wears shoes made of leather? Old <reading>coots</reading> (<ja>くつ</ja>). Old coots are so old that the only shoes they wore growing up were made from leather so they refuse to wear any shoes that aren’t made from leather. Crazy old coots.
data.reading_hint: Imagine some of these old coots busting into a modern shoe store and kicking over all the display stands and setting everything on fire because they hate non leather shoes so much. Hear the old coots screaming and babbling nonsense as they destroy the store.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> hits while you're <radical>farming</radical>, you'll have to wear really <kanji>thick</kanji> clothes to deal with it. The water is thick with fish and cars and other ripped-up debris too, which makes it even harder.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine putting on your thick farming suit as the tsunami comes at you. You hold onto your hoe and brace yourself for the wall of water.
data.reading_mnemonic: You knew to put on your <kanji>thick</kanji> tsunami-proof farming gear because <reading>No</reading>stradamus (<ja>のう</ja>) warned you it was coming. He sent a message to your brain yesterday so you'd know what to wear today.
data.reading_hint: Thanks Nostradamus, now I'm in my nice, thick gear, struggling to hoe my fields through this wall of tsunami water. But I'm not dead and I'm not wet.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Setting up a <radical>stand</radical> on the top of a <radical>mountain</radical>, you <radical>rake</radical> all the rocks to the <kanji>edge</kanji> of it. You want to clear the area around your stand, so you get your rake out and you rake all the stones and debris away from the stand and toward the edge of the mountain top. It also creates a small barrier around the edge as well.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself at the top of the mountain, holding the rake in your hands. Look over the edge. Feel the sinking feeling in your stomach as you realize how high up you really are.
data.reading_mnemonic: You set up this stand at the top of the mountain so you could give a speech to the world. But you need to look your best, so you decide to get a <reading>tan</reading> (<ja>たん</ja>). You lay next to the <kanji>edge</kanji> of the mountain, and prepare to tan. Everyone likes a person with a healthy tan.
data.reading_hint: Imagine yourself at the edge of this mountain getting your tan on. Feel the sun beating down on you and feel the fresh mountain breeze blowing over your body. It’s very relaxing.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> with a <radical>mouth</radical> eats a <radical>beggar</radical> and his <radical>stool</radical>, which were on the <radical>ground</radical> next to him, which seems to be a bit <kanji>extreme</kanji>, don't you think?
data.meaning_hint: The beggar was just sitting there on a stool! Why so extreme?
data.reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately we still haven’t come up with a good reading for <ja>きょく</ja>, but just try and remember this reading as <reading>Goku</reading> (<ja>ごく</ja>) from Dragon Ball Z and his strange step brother <reading>Kyoku</reading> (<ja>きょく</ja>). Goku and Kyoku are the beggars in this story, the ones performing all the <kanji>extremes</kanji>. First Goku gets eaten by the tree with the mouth, and then Kyoku gets eaten as well.
data.reading_hint: You know Goku from Dragon Ball, right? Imagine him doing all sorts of extreme things. Then imagine his less impressive brother, Kyoku, also doing extremes. And then they get eaten by the tree.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you ride a <radical>scooter</radical> you'll have a <radical>surplus</radical> of possible <kanji>route</kanji>s. Not only can you drive on any road, but you can ride on the sidewalk too!
data.meaning_hint: Okay, so it might not be legal to take the sidewalk route depending on where you live, but physically, you can do whatever you want because scooters are small.
data.reading_mnemonic: You decide to take the fastest <kanji>route</kanji>, since you have so many options, and drive on the sidewalk. However, in doing so you run over every single <reading>toe</reading> (<ja>と</ja>) on every single person trying to walk there.
data.reading_hint: Psh, whatever. They aren't your toes, and this is the fastet route! You'll name it the toe route and do whatever you want.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of your <radical>yoga</radical> class uses a special <radical>brush</radical> to stay <kanji>healthy</kanji>. She rubs the brush on her long arms and legs, and she never ever gets sick.
data.meaning_hint: If you want to be healthy too, just do yoga and rub this healthy brush all over your bod.
data.reading_mnemonic: Not everyone wants to be <kanji>healthy</kanji>, but <reading>Ken</reading> (<ja>けん</ja>) the samurai sure does. He needs to be ready at a moment's notice so he can do tasks for other people. He's at every class, rubbing himself down with the brush.
data.reading_hint: Imagine Ken, the picture of samurai health, doing yoga and getting that brush all up in those bits.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>canopy</radical> needs a <radical>brush</radical> and some <radical>water</radical> because it's gotten gross. When it's clean, you feel at <kanji>ease</kanji>, and at <kanji>peace</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Look at your dirty canopy. Feel irritated, aggravated, annoyed, and all similar feelings at it because it's not clean. Then, take some water to it and get brushing. When you're done, it's clean. Now, feel a feeling of ease come over you.
data.reading_mnemonic: You feel totally at <kanji>ease</kanji> looking at your canopy. Someone comes up behind you and starts massaging your shoulders. It's <ja><reading>こう</reading>いち</ja>. He wants you to feel even more at ease.
data.reading_hint: <ja>こういち</ja> says, "Yes. Feel at ease. Feel at peace. This is a good canopy you cleaned."

data.meaning_mnemonic: Inside the "<radical>Good</radical> <radical>Building</radical>" there's a single <kanji>guy</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Feel free to walk around the Good Building. There are no things or people, except for that one guy. Who is that guy.
data.reading_mnemonic: You talk to that <kanji>guy</kanji>. The only thing he does is offer you <reading>roe</reading> (<ja>ろう</ja>).
data.reading_hint: You try to talk to the guy, poke him, and even yell at him. But, all he does is hand you some fish roe. When you take it, he offers you more fish roe. What's up with this guy?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>thread</radical>s have to <radical>suit</radical> you if you want a good <kanji>salary</kanji>. No one is going to give you a salary if your clothes don't suit you. You have to look professional!
data.meaning_hint: When you see someone wearing a fancy suit that suits them, don't you wonder about how much their salary is?
data.reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>salary</kanji> is paid in <reading>cu</reading>cumbers (<ja>きゅう</ja>). Maybe you shouldn't have worn that cucumber tie when you interviewed for this job, even though it suited you well.
data.reading_hint: Imagine your salary being paid in cucumbers. Open that sweet paycheck and watch the cucumbers come tumbling out.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>scooter</radical> takes you to the <radical>barracks</radical>, <radical>drop</radical>s you off, and then goes in <kanji>reverse</kanji> all the way back home in the <kanji>opposite</kanji> direction.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine riding your scooter to the barracks. It literally drops you on the ground when you get there, and then drives in reverse back the opposite way you came.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your scooter going in reverse and leaving you here is opposite of what you want. You want to ride it back home when you're done, so you stuff the wheels with Gak (ぎゃく). If you don’t know what Gak is, check out this Gak commercial.
data.reading_hint: You Gak up the wheels so when the scooter tries to switch to reverse it gets stuck. Success! But now it can't go forward either. Darn you Gak, you tricked me again.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>giant</radical> radical and the <kanji>giant</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Massive!
data.reading_mnemonic: Just recently, a <kanji>giant</kanji> rampaged through Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (<ja>きょ</ja>), so now it's even smaller than before. Poor Little Kyoto.
data.reading_hint: See Little Kyoto after the giant rampaged through it. It looks even smaller and more pathetic than ever. Look at all the smoldering rubble and smell the smoke with your nose.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>canopy</radical> is over your <radical>car</radical> because your car is in <kanji>storage</kanji> in a large <kanji>warehouse</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: The canopy just protects your car from the elements as it sits in storage for long periods of time.
data.reading_mnemonic: Your car is in this <kanji>storage</kanji> <kanji>warehouse</kanji>, just sitting there. A <ja><reading>子</reading></ja> (<ja>こ</ja>) notices this, and decides to take your car on a joyride. You won't notice, right? You never drive it.
data.reading_hint: Imagine a kid sneaking into your canopy to steal your car that's in storage. Maybe it's two <ja>子</ja>s, one stacked on the other with a trench coat. One <ja>子</ja> works the pedals while the other <ja>子</ja> works the steering.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Pointing your magic solar powered wishing <radical>stick</radical> at the <radical>sun</radical>, you attain the <radical>legs</radical> of a <kanji>child</kanji>. You’re old and want young legs to carry you around, so you took your wishing stick that’s powered by the sun, and you wished for the legs of a child.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine yourself getting new legs. Legs that belong to a child. They’re limber and young and full of energy! Feel your legs of a child underneath you!
data.reading_mnemonic: As you delight in your new legs, <reading>Je</reading>sus (<ja>じ</ja>) descends from the sky. “My <kanji>child</kanji>,” he says, “why have you pointed the stick at the sun and wished for the legs of a child? You were already perfect, just as all of God’s children are perfect.”
data.reading_hint: Say back to Jesus, “I’m not your child Jesus! And you’re just jealous of my new legs! You wish you had the legs of a child, Jesus! Your legs are like super old!” Actually say this out loud, and remember how Jesus wishes he could be a child again too.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You got your <radical>ice</radical> <radical>orders</radical>. Of course, your ice orders are to make things <kanji>cool</kanji> and <kanji>cold</kanji>.
data.meaning_hint: Making things cool and cold are pretty much the only orders you'll hear from ice. Ice is very simple in that regard.
data.reading_mnemonic: How will you make things <kanji>cool</kanji> and <kanji>cold</kanji>? You'll use a special <reading>ray</reading> (<ja>れい</ja>) gun that shoots a cold ray.
data.reading_hint:
Imagine a cold ray coming out of your ray gun. Anything it touches becomes cold. "Stay cool, bird boy," you say.

Hint: when you see the radical <radical>orders</radical> it's fairly likely the reading will be <ja>れい</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Ice</radical> from the <radical>east</radical> is <kanji>frozen</kanji>. Well, of course, all ice is frozen, but ice from the east is like, really super frozen.
data.meaning_hint: Imagine this super frozen ice from the east. You’ve never seen anything quite like it before. It’s so frozen, it’s like it was frozen once and then frozen again. Twice frozen. Feel the ice and how freezing cold it is. It’s super cold, guys.
data.reading_mnemonic: Japan is a country in the east, and this ice was <kanji>frozen</kanji> in <ja><reading>とう</reading>きょう</ja>. <ja>とうきょう</ja> is really good at freezing frozen things, so it makes sense that this frozen ice came from there.
data.reading_hint: Imagine being in <ja>とうきょう</ja> and seeing all this frozen ice. Hear people speaking Japanese all around you as you touch and feel the freezing twice-frozen ice.
